It can't match the speed of the AX6000, but as least it's dependable.I wish I could return it, but I'm left to sell it.

reviewTitle: Good but not what I expected.
reviewDescription: I found it works fine for a simple AP.  For an AP with a minimalist firewallIt left a lot to be desired for my needs. No SSL certificate could be installed and SSH connectivity was not anywhere to be found.

I'd say it's marginally faster than the Netgear C6300 (with the intel puma) it replaced and marginally more stable as far as speed (drops)  (yes, internet co's do throttle) even with real debrid used for stability.  This goes for wifi6 connection to firestick max as well.  Got it working, though,  with many adjustments moving wifi devices for better signal (this unit  not as strong as Netgear it replaced initially for wifi signal).  Was really surprised after reading all the hype,  even connected to a new motorola MB8611 cable modem.  The price was right, though.  Guess you get what you pay for.  All in all, system is working now and generally happy.  Streaming to Shield Pro via LAN and wifi to fire cube 1st gen and firestick max.  Clean caches constantly and close background apps to keep speeds topped out.  Router restarts on occasion help as well.

Overall a good router but the 2.4GHz band has problems. I have two of these routers and both experience the same issue. I have to constantly reset the router to get some devices that need the band to connect and they’ll get kicked off the band as well. The 5GHz band seems to work great. There is the capability to mesh the bands but then nothing connects or stays connected that uses the 2.4GHz frequencies.

reviewTitle: Decent but firmware is simplistic and lacks features. No guest bandwidth control.
reviewDescription: Right off no Guest network throttling or bandwidth control for devices. Can't use DD-WRT or OpenWrt on these despite the FCC ruling that they had to. On the Amazon page near the bottom you can read the legal disclaimer which includes "This router may not support all the mandatory features as ratified in Draft 3.0 of IEEE 802.11AX specification." So it's illegally blocking 3rd party software.Despite all the "beamforming" hooplah it just follows where you point the antennas. I've got DSL currently (fiber supposed to be here a month ago is why I bought it) so slow speeds and the Wi-Fi 6 is not any faster than old modem/wifi connection. Yes I have an AX card in computer, Yes I understand that straight speed isn't everything but still no advantage.So I'm back to looking for a router. Just glad I didn't shell out for the AX50 or more expensive TP-Link routers as they are all reporting the same thing and lack of decent firmware.Dang, return window just closed.

The router is easy to set up. I had it up and going in just a few minutes. The interface is nice and easy to work with.The USB port that can have an external drive plugged into so you have a network drive everyone can access doesn't work quite right. The primary computer that is plugged into the ethernet port can access that drive but no other computers on the network can access it. I spent over an hour on tech-support troubleshooting this and they had no idea how to make it work. I was able to plug it into a usb drive on the main computer and make it a share drive and all the other computers were able to access.The routers wifi seems to shut down occasionally for a few minutes. I lost connectivity from my phone for 5 minutes and another time my Nest thermostat couldn't connect to the wifi for almost 10 minutes.Overall I like the interface and how easy the router is to use but it seems a little quirky in some of the features that don't work quite right. On router at this price those features not working quite right is annoying and costs them 2 stars.

reviewTitle: Settings are not as good as the older models.
reviewDescription: So far the router is performing as it should. I had no problems connecting all of my devices and they have not dropped. The problem I have is you cannot add a device manually to a blacklist, it will not allow it. You can, however, add manually to the whitelist. So, in order to prevent someone whose mac address I know I have to add ALL of my devices to a whitelist to prevent this one from getting on my wifi. Would have been easier to add this one to a blacklist. Now, since I am using a whitelist if a guest should want to use my guest network I have to add them to the whitelist or they can't use the guest wifi. Never had this problems with the older models. All TP-Link support would tell me is they would submit feedback to their team. Can't understand why they would change such an important setting.

I previously purchased a AX1800 which proved a bad investment as it would periodically stop working on WiFi ! This router which I bought on Amazon went past return date in December 2022. I went on a search for a hopefully very reliable router again and decided on the AX 5400 after reading so many positive reviews, only in the first month of use so far very happy. Just annoyed I wasted money on the AX1800 that lasted less than 3 months on the WiFi side. I'm running up to 32 clients wired and wireless at any given time, the 1800 couldn't handle it the AX 5400 can.
I wanted separate 2.4 and 5g for my not so smart devices that can't handle mesh. This was plug and play. The app has limited setup but you can still just dial in the old fashioned way
The range extends from the bottom floor to the to the top floor of a 1200 sq ft condo. A little issue of updating the OS to get out working.
This router has been a blessing to us!  we never lose our internet connection with it!  Dont hesitate to order this it is affordable and works great!
It was very simple to setup!  Plug and play.  Just follow the instructions. It look nice and works good!

reviewTitle: Works Very Well with TP-Link RE600X OneMesh Range Extender
reviewDescription: Functions as advertised.  Being advanced user I would prefer a little more granularity in the advanced configuration menus but the bottom line for this router is that is the best bang-for-the buck (i.e. value for your money) you are going to find in a WiFi 6 dual band router, taking into account stability of operation.  There may be some competitors in the price range but check the reviews for user comments about stability such as need for rebooting every so often.  This AX21 has gone over 30 days without reboot and is performing as perfectly as it did right after that last reboot.  Now, I did have an issue initially that caused me to down rate this router initially, but that turned out to be a rather dumb error in configuring it right out of the box. Once I caught that I meant to update my review but got sidetracked and so am now just updating it to give this router the credit it deserves.  House is a single level 1800 sq ft living space plus approx 800 sq ft three and half car attached garage.  The garage floor is sealed and the exterior walls and overhead doors insulated to make the garage usable as extra space for the home in add'n to containing vehicle and motorcycle (seal coated floor).  My point here is the AX21/600X combo covers the entire structure both living space and the garage with garage featuring a streaming client (4K TV).  The signal strength admittedly is down to approximately half at farthest point in garage but that is still impressive at the price point of this Wifi 6 mesh network setup using only one extender (the RE600X).  Other side of the kitchen wall (exterior wall) that the 600X is plugged into is a small in-ground pool area and the AX21/RE600X mesh network signal is no less that about 75% strength out there.  These results are nothing short of phenomenal in my opinion at the price point, but admittedly I got both for around 20% off each during Holiday season discounts by the TP-Link Store here on Amazon.  And again, the stability is commendable-- these two devices working together in the OneMesh configuration just keep on keeping on, with no throughput or latency issues in over 30 days on un-rebooted use.  If you saw my RE600X review you may note comment on long reboot time and think my statements are not consistent, but take heart: that observation was during the initial setup of the RE600X and is not relevant to my statement that the pair have not required a reboot since.  One caveat:  The household consists of just two persons, and device load on the network is rarely more than 3 or 4 devices actively using wifi data at same time.  Your mileage may vary with higher device load on this same setup.One final note about the AX21 WiFi 6 router.  It accepts prime number Beacon Intervals without issue.  I am currently using a Beacon Interval of 167 and DTIM of 1 and have found this to be the sweet spot between throughput, latency, and client battery drain for this router.  My previous router was a TP-Link Archer C7 Wifi 5 and 127 was it's sweet spot for Beacon Interval.  I utilize a prime number Beacon due to local crowding on the 2.4ghz medium in my neighborhood.Hard to go wrong with the AX21/RE600X combo if you have a small to medium living space !!
I attached this router to the modem Spectrum provided and it works great. App is easy to use and understand.
This router does all I need to connect 2 TV sets in a 3200 square foot house. The coverage is good enough for all streaming services we use and I would recommend.
Had an old (9/10 years old) NG that did OK. With this, I'm getting over 100 mbps with 5g. Incredible.

reviewTitle: The router is great, Spectrum is just horrible.
reviewDescription: It would be nice to have internet that used it’s full potential.

I bought this instead of renting one from my provider. It pays for itself in less than a year. I have a one story 3 bedroom home. I opted not to get the boosters and reception throughout the house is good.

reviewTitle: A little confusing to set up
reviewDescription: It works great but despite all the antennas this does not reach my whole home. I would need a mesh system to use this at it's full capacity. Also this router is pretty confusing to install and not everyone will have an ez time setting it up. It it not plug-n-play. I do get my full speeds though which is nice.

I have had many TP-Link products in the past and they are usually full featured. I wanted to use this device as a Wi-Fi bridge to my main router. After looking at the all the options in the user interface I finally called Tech support and they said that this router does NOT support a Wi-Fi bridge function.  I was very disappointed, and I returned the item.

This product seems to work fine if near it but it has to be connected to the router so kind of hard to move it far from the router itself! Also seems that I don’t get a lot of distance with it. I have about the same mbs as if I didn’t have the extra “router”. Hope this helps

reviewTitle: Hard to set up but works ok
reviewDescription: Major pain to set this up but it seems to work fine.

My WiFi is better and reaches throughout the house. The reason why I’m not leaving 5 stars is because only two Ethernet cable ports work. I don’t want to go through the return process so I have a splitter otw so hopefully it fixes my issue.

Worked great when it arrived. It is NOT compatible with Xfinity modems and routers. One day before I got the Xfinity equipment, it stopped receiving the internet signal from my first router so it became useless. I wouldn’t recommend it.
This router allowed my signal to constantly drop for internet and usually just at the wrong time. I had the cable company install their own router and it works t least 95% better.
There are two differences between this router and my old one.1. This router looks cooler2. This router does not let my iPhone connect to itNot recommended for iPhone users

It does what it says it does, but the LED's on the front never blinks so you never know if there is any activity. And to me I just find that risky because I like to know if my devices are sending or receiving data via Wi-Fi. Also I felt that the user interface lacked so many of the advanced networking features that even the cheap phone company router's provide so that was a HUGE issue of mine but it might not be of yours. It all depends on how easy you want things I suppose. But that's my two cents so to speak, I went back to using my old, or well rather just other Wi-Fi 6 router for the more advanced features, along with the AI protection.

reviewTitle: Not so easy to set up
reviewDescription: Once I got it working with tech help from my internet provider it works as advertised. No wi-fi pauses, fast, reliable so far.

reviewTitle: great range, solved my issues with Comcast
reviewDescription: My devices kept getting kicked off my Comcast provided gateway and I'd have to reset it to get them to reconnect. Happened with more than one gateway and they were no help.  So I bought this as the router for all my home devices to connect to then connected it via cable to the Comcast gateway, problem solved.  Range is better than the gateway and I no longer have any issues.
Fast shipping and great product
Improvement over my older wi-fi. Very happy for the upgrade

reviewTitle: Fast Router, nice features in app for priority access etc.
reviewDescription: Fast Router, nice features in app for priority access etc.  Getting much faster speeds.  Right in the APP you can select certain devices to get priority or you can disconnect and block things.  Very nice
I needed a new router and came across this one. So far, so good.

reviewTitle: Drastic and Considerable Power and Reach
reviewDescription: This router has been a game-changer for my home network, significantly improving my overall capabilities and services, especially in the realm of gaming and video editing.The Archer AX10000 truly lives up to its reputation as a speed machine. These speeds have provided a seamless gaming experience and have made 4K video editing a breeze.It excels at detecting and optimizing gaming streams, ensuring that my gaming sessions remain immersive and free from disruptions.This router makes it easy to connect a wide array of devices, accommodating the needs of my most demanding household, which include seven people using numerous devices. Network performance always runs at its peak. My gaming and video editing tasks are handled with utmost efficiency.A number of my children perform a myriad of things on their devices and it is evident that the router delivers data to multiple devices simultaneously. This has significantly reduced lag, ensuring a smooth online experience for all connected devices.I've found the compatibility with OneMesh supported range extenders, such as the TP-Link AX3000 WiFi 6 Range Extender, to be a practical solution for extending Wi-Fi coverage in my four-level home. Connecting the extender was a simple process, and it effortlessly covers the hard-to-reach areas.Works with All Internet Service Providers: The Archer AX10000's compatibility with a wide range of internet service providers is truly appreciated. I had no issues setting it up with my existing provider (Xfinity), and it has vastly improved my network capabilities and services.To highlight the sheer impact of this router, I'd like to mention that I upgraded from seven Google Wifi units to the TP-Link Archer AX10000, and the improvement has been nothing short of remarkable. My gaming and video editing performance have seen substantial enhancements.While the user interface has its challenges, it's far from insurmountable, and the benefits of this router more than make up for it.In conclusion, the TP-Link Archer AX10000 is a top-tier router that has revolutionized my home network. Its phenomenal speed, gaming optimization, and connectivity options have dramatically improved my overall network capabilities and services. This router has been easy to assemble and has truly taken my gaming and video editing performance to new heights.

reviewTitle: Affordable upgrade to Wifi 6 and WPA3
reviewDescription: This router replaced one a few years older that was having issues with multiple streams during the pandemic. The price of the AX21 was very fair, but especially for all the technological upgrades this model includes. Wifi 6 and advanced WPA3 security are nice to have for future proofing, and the beamforming, MU-MIMO and OFDMA protocols for handling multiple devices at once have all made an appreciable difference in our WiFi quality. This model also supports TP-Link's "OneMesh" feature, allowing you to create your own mesh WiFi network for poor coverage areas in larger homes. Also of note is that the AX21 can be enabled to automatically update its firmware, which is a very convenient feature if you want to keep your network secure without having to manually check for and apply updates every few weeks or months. The settings menu is easy to navigate and has many options to customize this device for your needs.About our coverage:Despite its central location on the second floor, our older router had trouble fully covering the edges of our ~3,000 square foot two story home. Streaming video in those areas often buffered, cut out, or simply failed to load at times. Since replacing the older router with the AX21 in the exact same location, there are absolutely no dead zones at all inside our home. In fact, our speeds in those areas have gone up substantially when compared to our previous router and it has solved our streaming issues completely. We also get a strong signal throughout our yard.We specifically purchased this model because we were skeptical, given our past struggles with WiFi coverage, that any router by itself would completely cover our house. Having the ability to purchase other OneMesh compatible devices to expand coverage to the fringes of our home was a very attractive proposition for us and influenced our purchase of this model over others without mesh support. We fully expected to eventually purchase another device or two in order to expand our network to the edges of our home. After setting up the AX21 and testing it out, we realized that purchasing additional devices would be unnecessary for us, which makes me even more pleased about the price we paid to upgrade!Summary:The AX21 is a very nice and affordable upgrade if you are currently using a router that is more than a few years old. It has many of the newest high end features and should remain relevant for years to come. The price is very fair based on the tremendous increase in quality we've experienced since upgrading. The support of the OneMesh system to build your own mesh network is also a great benefit for those with large homes that currently suffer from WiFi coverage problems. However, based on our experiences, I would recommend trying just this router first and purchasing additional OneMesh compatible devices after testing. You may find that this router alone provides all the coverage you need, we did!
Had a little trouble keeping connection at first, but now it’s working great!

TP Link makes great routers and wireless access points.  Our company uses TPlink WIFI access points throughout the facility and they've worked flawlessly for years.  After some bad luck with ASUS wireless routers at home, I decided to go with TP link and I'm glad I did.  The WIFI signal is very strong and it covers my 3 BR house better than previous wireless routers.  We run many devices... Rokus, Chromecast, Tablets, Smart Phones, Desktop and Laptop computers.... and there's always plenty of WIFI signal for each device.  I  get good, strong signal outside on my deck, storage building and yard.  The Tether smart phone app provided by TPlink makes it easy to keep track of and execute firmware updates.  Excellent quality router for a good price.  Highly recommended.
Excelente

I been using the Apple router for so long that Apple doesn’t even make routers anymore. I had been having trouble with streaming. I thought between that and my Sonos speakers and echo devices and phone, that maybe the issue was the router. This came recommended by a quick google search. Of course it took some work to figure out the password and then make a new password and a whole slew of other issues that took 30 minutes to an hour to work out. I went to fast.com to check out my speeds and now I’m getting better speed from my streaming services and all my devices. Very happy with the brand and the upgrade

reviewTitle: Not a bad router, but one issue..
reviewDescription: Can't seem to get Airplay to work. It was running perfectly fine on my previous router. Airplay should work on any router as far as I know. But somehow not on this one. Contacted support- no help. Wonder is anyone else has Airplay issues?
Router works as expected, although its strength is no better than the D-Link router it replaced, which is a disappointment.
This is my 3rd Archer router. And it is the best.  Easy set up and good performance.

reviewTitle: Challenging to get connected, but tech support succeeded!
reviewDescription: It wasn’t an easy process to get the router working with my new modem.  Tech support from Von Ibinez kept trouble shooting until the connection was working.  It took about a hour to fix the issues.  Very appreciative of his ongoing effort!

reviewTitle: In Beta Phase, just installed and updated devices...
reviewDescription: Product Archer AX21, working after calling Ms Mona, @Tech Support. Directions could be better described. LED identities hard to see, accompanied brochure had no description. Thank You Mona Shan!
we have an increase in usage of wifi in our home and what we had wasn't adequate. So far it has improved the connection and have problems.
Easy to setup, dual bands can be combined for better performance. Better price purchased online.

Easy set upFast wifiEasy to create guest networkI have a lot of smart devices and automation's on top of cameras.  The original ISP router worked ok, but noticed the devices would always drop or lose signal.Tried a mesh system and boy was the speed great.  In fact the speed is/was better on the mesh than this but the fact remained the same the smart devices still would lose connection and disconnect.  A few times the whole mesh disconnected but thats a whole different review.  Connected this, updated the smart devices, and in fact nothing has disconnected or lost signal upstairs or  anywhere in the house.
Worked just fine, but our internet provider installed one so we returned this unit.

reviewTitle: Seems to Glitch Quite A Bit
reviewDescription: Heavily researched this item prior to purchase.  Easy to install.  I have noticed that my podcasts seem to hiccup (stop and then start again) with this new router.  Haven't noticed problems with TV streaming or other wi-fi products as of yet.

I am using AT&T internet, with my router next to a refrigerator, not the best spot. On my main floor, I'm getting about 350 mbps. On my second floor my AT&T router about 98mbs in farthest corner, and 258 right above router. Pretty good. I added the TP-Link to the house via ethernet cord, and now my speed at farthest point is 258 mbps. Not much different than AT&T router. Before this,I had a 5 year old router hooked into Ethernet, and was only getting 17 mbps. Great product, for me, if you have ethernet available, and are using an older router.
We needed one upstairs and this one works really good

reviewTitle: Good quality router with a consistent signal
reviewDescription: I purchased this router to use in place of the wireless functionality in my wireless Gateway. Overall, the router is very efficient and I am not experiencing any drop offs of my network like I was when  using the equipment provided by my cable company. I like that I can control some of the router functions using the Alexa TP link skill.  I am, however, experiencing some minor connection difficulties with a couple of my IOT devices ever since I got this router which is the only reason that I give it four stars.
Give good Internet
The Tech PAUL DOMINIC FERNANDO PERRERAS was great and helped me through the whole set up process because it was a bit challenging.

reviewTitle: Problems resolved with warranty support - rating and review update
reviewDescription: Original: It was a good router while it lasted, but I expected it to last a couple years, at least, not less than one!  When I went to register it for warranty support the TP-Link website said the serial number was not from the US.  I had to provide further proof.  So we'll see if they make good on the warranty.  Meanwhile I need wi-fi NOW, so I'm off to buy a new router.  If TP-Link covers this dead one and I end up with two routers, then I'll have a backup for when the next one dies, which is not a bad thing.Update: I was able to register my router in a couple of days and contacted warranty support.  They replied quickly via email.  (I had the option of email or phone.)  There was a list of steps to try to get wifi working again.  I was going carefully through the list and suddenly noticed the wifi light on the router was green.  My router is not dead after all and I'm using it now.I have the usual number of devices: TV (streaming), phone, laptop which could all be in use at once.  I generally have no issues.  I reboot once in a while, but I noticed on the app you can schedule a regular reboot which might be a good idea.  It's a good, reasonably priced router for anyone who doesn't need anything fancy.
Not biggest difference if you're looking for it to be faster but stop the lag
This was a step up for my archer 1800. This has doubled the coverage in my home and can receive in the driveway and backyard. I only complaint is sometimes the signal does drop.

reviewTitle: Excellent signal, though terrible set-up issues
reviewDescription: I have been using this for about 5 weeks, and the signal is still going strong. I actually get faster speeds than with an ethernet cable. Set-up was terrible, though, as my laptop could not access the router webpage, and the router would not access the internet. I will share the details in case anyone else encounters the same issue.I tried multiple troubleshooting steps without success. (e.g., My modem was not the issue, as I accessed the internet fine with my laptop directly connected to the modem.) I had actually purchased two of these routers, with the plan to daisy chain them--turns out I didn't need to do that once I found the wifi signal to be so strong--and I couldn't access either router's webpage, so I didn't think I got two duds. I contacted technical support, and they wanted to access my laptop to see what was going on when I attempted to access the router webpage, but I pointed out my laptop couldn't access the internet through the router, so they wouldn't be able to access my laptop. We ended up having a painfully inefficient email exchange--waiting 20-30 minutes for responses--to troubleshoot, and after 2-3 hours I was FINALLY able to access the router webpage by having my laptop directly connected to the modem, the router NOT directly connected to anything (not the modem or laptop), and the laptop accessing the router via wifi. Technical support would not venture to explain why I had had such trouble with the set-up, as they said they only cared that the setup was finally accomplished. (Hmph, OK.)

Positive: I use Class Collaborate for teaching. Before using this device, I often got kicked out of class because. With this device, I no longer get kicked out of class. Which is great since I am the instructor.Negative: it could be that my Internet sucks. But when I started using this device, the Internet worked much faster. I have only had this for a few months and noticed that it has slowed down quite a bit.Perhaps I am doing something wrong. But it worked for a while, and now it doesn't work as well. So . . .

reviewTitle: Wanted to love this router but couldn't
reviewDescription: Bought this router along with a CM2000 modem to replace the gateway provide by my ISP. The modem was reccommended by the ISP installer and this router seemed to be way better than the one he suggested to go along with the modem.The good:Super easy set up.Blazing high speeds.Easy to build my home network of static IPs.The range of this thing is unreal, like the title said, I wanted to love this router and I did, but I had one HUGE occuring issue.The issue:Internet would drop at my house 5-6 times a day. With each time, my router would require a reboot in order for the internet to work again. Prior to this, I never had any issues with the provided gateway or linksys router. After a couple months calling TP link Tech support and looking at logs and trying to figure out what was wrong, if it was my modem, router or switch, I had come to the realization that my modem and switch were both netgear and the TP link router just not compatible with them. I went out and just bought a netgear router on sale one day to try and take the router out of the equation and everything has been rock solid ever since. Now I have a $380 paper weight that I am hoping to use a possible access point if somone doesnt want to buy it off of me at a step discount.TL:DRGreat router but wasnt compatible with my modem and switch.

reviewTitle: Old stock. Shipped old v1 hardware from last year
reviewDescription: Had an issue during setup and while talking to support they asked me twice if it was new and then said its an older model and there is a "fixed" V2, felt bummed about it.  The latest firmware is a year old for a wifi 6 router not good at all.Its also very watered down feature wise.  Link aggregation for example only works for port 2 and 3 on an 8 port switch?  Not cool.  I do regret buying this as I was going to use the link aggregation on a par of NAS with 2x1GB links.  Cant do that.I ideally wanted something like this but with 2.5GB managed port and was willing to pay double.  In hindsight I should have got a separate PF sense router, switch and WAP.  There is no solid all in one out there and the high end gaming ones look like an upside down stool for a toddler.  For someone with an engineering background and likes to tinker, this isn't for you.  This is for your folks house, something you can walk them through setting up over the phone.  Again, this is for a no technical person that wants something that is plug and play.I still have to test VPN, if the bw is crap or has issues even with the quad core CPU, Id say its an overpriced basic router with a couple high end features available but very poorly implemented to justify charging about 100 more than its worth. The only real stand out feature is built in 8 port 1GB LAN switch.
This seems like a great product but it only has a ethernet port. If you have a cable connection this product isn't for you.

Never could get internet so returned it. Old router worked fine but kept going out, old modem seemed to be OK but this router would not get internet when connected. Returned it and got an Assis Surfboard. Seamless installation and did not have to call Assis. You have to call provider and router company with this model. Also, app did not work as there was no internet and there was no internet because the app didn’t work! Very happy with Assis, no problems and great speed!

reviewTitle: Almost sent back due to poor tech support...!
reviewDescription: I had a very hard time setting up this router due to extremely poor tech support. I was put on a 20 minute wait on the online chat support, with the option to type in useful information while I waited. So I did so, putting down my router model, my ISP, and the nature of my problem, explaining what I had tried already.When "Alberto" finally came on, he started asking me the very questions I had taken time to answer; "What is the model # of your router? What ISP do you have?" and so on. When he asked if I plugged my router directly into the modem, I said "No, I use a 5 port switch, which should not be a problem, because the router I am upgrading from, the TP-Link AC 1900, works fine using the same Ethernet port I am trying to use now. Yet with the AX6000 I get a 'WAN port is not connected' error message."So the tech guy immediately sees a way to get out of helping me, and says: "It will only work connected directly to the modem." And then he hangs up!I knew he was wrong because I have used the other router that way for years. So, I spent about 3 more hours figuring out the problem myself...!Turns out I needed to Clone the MAC address of my previous PC (I copied the previously cloned MAC address still present in the firmware settings of my previous router), and, when misteriously that did not solve the problem, even though based on my online research it should, unplugging the 5 port switch for a couple of minutes and then turning it back on, miraculously fixed the problem...!I honestly think both steps were needed, as I could not get things previously working even when connecting directly to the modem, unless I put the cloned MAC settings in.Once I solved these issues, I have to say this is an EXCELLENT router...! Blazing fast speeds, amazing range, and great stability, so far, on this first day testing it.I hope anyone experiencing the problems I had is helped by my post, because you certainly will not get any decent help from the morons they have doing tech support at TP-Link (or whoever they outsource to, if that is the case).
The paper instructions aren't very instructive! I had to call an expert to set it up for me. Once set up it worked very well
Had a hard time connecting. App did not work will, had to have my comp. tech come make connection.

reviewTitle: Don't buy if you want to configure you're network
reviewDescription: Good wifi router for normal user.  Lacks configuration options. No support for custom firmware for advanced users.Pros:Wifi radios have good signal.QoS does a decent job of sharing internet bandwidthCons:No configuration for local Vlans.Doesn't work well with other TP-LINK mesh offerings.Will not run openwrt, dd-wrt, tomato, etc.

reviewTitle: REALLY want to give this 5 stars, BUT....
reviewDescription: I just cant give it 5 stars. It has one glaring issue, that isnt common, and isnt listed in the device description. That issue is, the device puts out ONE signal. Therefore I cant Choose if I want a particular device on the 2.4 channel, and a different device on the 5ghz channel.... as I have been able to do with every router.... EVER!. I have a laptop in my deck, that I NEED to use the 5ghz signal, and cant do that. So it chooses which channel I connect to. WHen I am able to have it connect on 5ghz, I average 450mbs. On the 2.4 ghz, 87mbs tops. I cant have that, and never had that issue before I bought this modem/router. It also drops internet connection often. It only lasts for a second, as I get a little notice on the screen that is has been disconnected, and then reconnected. Other than these 2 issues, it has performed flawlessly. BUT, a router of this quality shouldnt have these issues.

reviewTitle: Performs better than the AC4000 for a 2 story home
reviewDescription: We have a two story home with the modem upstairs in a room over the garage.  Many devices downstairs would struggle in the afternoon (Ring doorbell, Samsung TV, etc).  With about 30 wireless devices  total my my TP-Link AC40000 worked pretty well and was way better than anything else at the time including more expensive Asus.The range and speed are better, hands down no question.  Haven't had any issues with the older devices either as this allows 2.4g, where other makes don't.  SO my older amcrest camera and my older Ring doorbell.I had to disable the QOS as my Samsung Q series and Vizio M series TVs would freeze up periodically.  I haven't noticed any issues since then and most of my heavy traffic is ethernet so hopefully that stays stable.  Speeds are better of course without QoS, but we're working with about 500mbs Spectrum.I thought the interface was fine, a little goofy with gamer page that didn't make sense, but it let me do whatever I needed to and explained a couple features I didn't see before.  If you forget the IP you used, it also helps with finding your way with a built in sniffer that directs to the proper page.Another nice thing was after initial testing, I just used the same SSID and password and all but one device used it successfully, which was a huge time saver.Side note.  I actually ran this plugged into one of the LAN ports of the AC4000 which didn't work at first, but after some tinkering with settings.  It assigned 192.168.1.1 vs 192.168.0.1 which is default and what the older router uses.  So it allowed me to test devices and login to the portal without having to commit fully and change everything, just wired devices wouldn't work.  Just an FYI as I was using it as an access point at first just to see how it performed, which was good too, then switched to normal mode.  It would NOT grab an IP through a switch, it had to be plugged into one of the ports of the older router.8 ports vs 4 on most routers is also nice as I'm using a switch for all the other stuff that I may be able to get rid of now.  Link aggregation is available as well.The price seems high, as all these do frankly, but for me it seems to work the way I need it to so far and reach further, run faster and hopefully avoid freezes as the AC4000 was starting to do a couple times a week (which could be the modem, so can't knock it).  The faster processor should help too.Depending on your situation, this is a luxury choice as the AC4000 really did a great job for a long time reaching further out than any other router I tried, which were several including high line ASUS that were 4x the cost and performed worse with no 2.4 for older devices.So far I'm happy with performance, ease of setup and using same SSID connected most things automatically so I'd recommend this router if your budget allows it and it tests out ok on your network.UPDATE: So after a year, I noticed a new wireless cam, and all my downstairs devices having issues losing connections for a few minutes to an hour.  I changed ONE setting from AUTO to manual channel selection (they give you 1-5 and no indication of what they actually are) for wireless and they all immediately did better.  I knew this because 1 camera was literally 1 foot away from another and was barely working before the change.  Now they both work well and the finicky TVs are more stable .. so farUPDATE 2: This router has problems with Samsung TVs.  TV shows full signal strength, but no data flow.  everything else seems to work fine.  Qseries.  It drops everything once in a while and if i had to do over again, I'd buy a different brand because I'd like to NEVER be bothered by this again and spending this kind of money should buy you that.

reviewTitle: Not a gaming router - performance ruined by the software. Do not recommend.
reviewDescription: **Edit** I'm waiting return, and have swapped back to my TP Link Archer AX50 (AX3000). I thought I'd be able to see an obvious difference in performance on my network. I am very surprised to say that on all my wired LAN connections, using Cat8, not even a measurable difference. On the wifi devices in my home, no consistent difference in speed, however the range is slightly better (slight, like about 10ish feet) where that speed extends to. That said, AX50 costs $109, this router cost me $349. The software on the AX10000 is far worse than that of the AX50 as well. The only disadvantages to the AX50 that would matter in price is that although TP-Link said they were going to release Onemesh for the AX50, instead they released the AX55 with that feature. No mesh for AX50. Also dual vs tri band, even though for most ppl this will not significantly be missed. For anyone not using Mesh...the AX50 will go toe to toe with the AX10000 for 99% of all of us that use simple networks in their home. Pass on this router, the AX10000 is without a doubt a marketing wonder but overall an overhyped mess of gaming buzzwords that mean little to nothing.Not a gaming router, identical to the AX11000. TP-Link just literally put the word "Gaming" in front of normal router functions like firewall services, network diagnostics, QOS, etc. This router for being a high end router, has less overall software features than my older TPLink AX50 this was supposed to replace. At the very least the same but more obscured in the software than their non-gaming routers. And some important things you need to, but Cannot disable. I've reviewed all this below.Bought this router little over a week ago, and it was a legitimate upgrade over the TPLink AX50 (AX3000) router we had before. Had been running very well for the time I used it, until it started having issues suddenly after running perfectly well.  I and my wife both work IT from home full-time. Seemed good until 2 days ago we started having total meltdowns of our upload speed. Called my internet provider and spent an hour on the phone two days in a row because at about 2:30-3p each day my upload speed would crash but not download speed. Upload averages 38Mbps, we were suddenly getting .6Mbps if not zero. Download speeds while this happen were still over 900, but fluctuating constantly 400s-500s-800s..etc. After doing testing at the wall and outside, at the modem, and at the router we found the router to have the issue.This is a KNOWN issue with TP-Link, they have entire posts on their community site addressing it. But these steps do NOT resolve the issue.Worst problem and the reason this is my LAST TP-Link device purchase.. the issue seems to revolve around the software. You CANNOT turn off QOS as you can in my other TP-Link router. And the QOS determines its capacity on the connection from doing it's own internal speed test of your internet connection. The test is faulty, and will read very low upload and inaccurately. QOS then uses this faulty speed test measurement to set your connection speeds and its the default config. You can set it manually and bypass the speed test setting the Up/Download speed at 1000Mbps for both. But this causes its own issues with QOS. 2nd issue is that even with Antivirus on the router turned off it is STILL actively using the firewall services to block incoming traffic. There is no way to turn it completely off, and it contacts AVIRA 80k+ times a day for updates. This slows the CPU of the router and uses quite a lot of the router's memory reducing the efficiency and causing you to get slightly diminished overall.Bottom line, yesterday I setup a return with Amazon. My family's livelihood is on the line and this router caused us a lot of downtime. If TP-Link would just create a firmware release where you are not Forced into keeping QOS and Antivirus/Firewall services enabled full-time even when AV shows off. With this router and the AX11000 they are identical and all have this issue identically. People have complained for what looks like a very long time and TPLink is not resolving this issue in their firmware.

reviewTitle: It's great out of the gate, but slows down after the first lap ...
reviewDescription: Review title says it all really (short version).This router has good range and is capable of fast throughput, but it doesn't seem to be able to maintain that throughput. Smart connect / auto select for channels and channel width appears to be not too smart. I recently changed Internet providers from ATT Uverse fiber optic to Astound Internet (ATT jacked up their monthly rate). I ordered the  TP-Link Archer AX21 a week prior to the switch. I disabled the ATT Gateways router (Arris BGW210-700) and connected the Archer AX21 in IP passthrough mode (similar to Bridge mode) in it's place for a baseline comparison, and it compared well in range/signal strength and with speed tests (Ookla Speedtest.net) to the BGW210's WiFi speed and range. However, the speedtests wouldn't hold up over time whereas the ATT all-in-one Gateway held fairly constant WiFi speeds over the year I had it. I measured these speed tests with my laptop and router in the exact same locations. Direct ethernet connection to one of the router's ethernet ports confirmed my cable modem (Arris SB8200) and Astound Internet weren't the bottleneck and were consistently supplying advertised speed of 400 Mbps (in excess of 400 Mbps actually).Since Smart connect/auto channel select wouldn't maintain speeds, I switched channels manually and increased channel width to 40 MHz (from 20 MHz). That would usually boost the link speeds and speed tests back to par. But it wouldn't sustain speeds. TP-Link support never really offered any solutions or even anything to try. They'll respond, and will go through the motions, but they had nothing substantive to offer. So I returned this router and purchased an ASUS RT-AX55 to replace it. Got it two days ago and so far so good. It is on Smart Connect and performing well. A little too early to review it yet but I am pleased with it thus far.Bottom line for me is the TP-Link Archer AX21 didn't consistently meet its advertised performance capabilities. I prefer a horse that doesn't require me to constantly whip it to run. I was logging into the router and switching channels several times a day to speed it back up. As an aside, Amazon made the return process easy overall although I wish they had a better choice in "reason for returning". I selected "Broken or defective" with defective being closer to the truth, but I would call it "doesn't meet advertised capabilities" or "doesn't meet expectations". I'm sure from TP-Link's perspective that isn't broken or defective. You plug it in, connect it, and it works. I won't be surprised if it is resold as new or possibly "renewed" and most users will be oblivious to its shortcomings.Some might think well, your WiFi speeds are location specific/walls/distance/competing WiFi signals/Bla Bla/Etc. The ATT Gateway's router didn't experience any issues with any of that, and the TP-Link was placed in the same location as is/was it's replacement, the ASUS AX55, and my laptop speedtests for all three located in the same location. What I can't say for sure is if this performance is specific to my particular router, or the model itself. The TP-Link gets good reviews overall, but I did read some reviews stating performance degrades over time, or something to that effect, so at least a few others had a similar issue. Also, I did update the firmware when I first set it up and used the router from Jan 10 - Feb 2, so a sufficient trial period to gauge performance.

reviewTitle: Not Quite the SAME - Watch your Hardware Versions
reviewDescription: Sadly, this is one of my first bad review.About a year ago, I ordered this box. It was nearly flawless in its function and filled its promises with glory. I loved it so much, I bought another for a different network. As I was setting it up, I discovered that the "New" one was not New at all. No, it was not a refurbished unit or a returned one. In the pictures, you will notice the hardware versions are not the same. The Hardware Version 2 is my older unit.I contacted the seller (Amazon) and had to speak to them on the phone. Even then, they were vexed by this issue. Another unit was sent out to replace the version 1 hardware unit, but it too was only Version 1. Well, technically it was hardware version of 1.6. Still, not a version 2 as the one I needed.On the bottom of the box, in the same line as the Model Number, the tail end is the version number and is clearly listed as V2. We will get back to this point later.The replacement box, the Hardware Version stated it was 1.6. I was hoping that this was a typo and continued to open the box. Upon inspection of the labels on the bottom of the router, I was met with the same information. A final check of the firmware confirmed the wrong hardware version was again shipped to me. Not Version 2 hardware.Looks like I may be returning both of the recent units purchased from Amazon as soon as I can find the correct version from some place like Office Depot, Staples, Micro Center, NewEgg, TigerDirect Business, Lowes or even Best Buy. The problem is, most will NOT check their stock or even their stock levels if you call them. They literally don't know what they have.  It appears Amazon is no different.Even seeking help from tp-link themselves was fruitless. Most vendors will take their product info directly off of the manufacturers website without any attention to the hardware versions and their differences. So, you end up with a ton of misleading info concerning capabilities that the product they may actually be selling. Essentially, selling old gear that can't match up with the new listed capabilities listed. Last I checked, this is often called Bait and Switch or false advertising.Integrity is evidently a lost art now. It boils down to a fault in communications between the vendors and the manufacturers. Its the consumer who pays the price in more ways than one. Sadly, it appears that nobody cares to do anything about it but report it as "Feedback."There is a decided difference in hardware between versions 1.6 and version 2 concerning chip functionality and expandability. But the biggest thing deals with support for the chipset for updates. Hardware V1 will NEVER get any updates!!Check the hardware version on the outside of the box and on the bottom of the router. There IS a difference and they are not telling you.

I bought one of these for 140.00 on June 25, 2022.  It stopped working last weekend, 6 weeks after the warranty expired, so had to buy a new router due to a defective router so I can work today, as I work from home as a computer consultant, I didn't have time over the weekend to even check on the warranty until today.I have an older TP-LINK TL-WDR4300 I bought back in 2015 that is still working as a WiFi switch upstairs with no issues at all.  This router worked well until it crashed and wouldn't even let you go through setup after resetting.  Basically it just died.The longevity of  this model is not worth the money I paid to die so short after warranty.  Hoping my new TP-Link AX5400 lasts longer.  If not, I'll try another brand that lasts longer.

reviewTitle: Its ok but its not the power house it claims to be
reviewDescription: So my old Netgear R7800 gave up and i had to replace it.  Knowing I had a few WIFI6 devices and a growing list of devices I decided on the AX6000.  On paper it looks great. It looked as if it would fit my needs.  After about a week of testing I have to say I am pretty disappointed.  I placed the AX6000 in the same location as the R7800.  I am on fiber, 1 Gig connection.  As far as speed i see no change at all.Signal strength is pretty much the same so there are no coverage issues.  The R7800 was mount on the wall.  The AX6000 has its indicator on the top but mounting it on the wall was not desirable due to the antenna orientation.  That said it had to go on a shelf in the same location.I thought maybe a firmware update or maybe moving it around would improve things.  Both wired and wireless speeds are basically the same as the previous router.The interface is far better.  The UI is OK, but not stellar.  The application for the phone is OK and much better than Netgear.There are some pretty pathetic options in the UI however.The big one I ran into right away was logging.  You can send the logs via SMTP but you get no options for ports.  That said its not going to work at all unless you are using a super insecure mail server or a mail server locally.  You can't do SSL or TLS.  There are no options to include a port for this and including one causes it to bail out.The only other option is to login and save locally.  There is no syslog, or method to save locally on the device.It is strange that TPLink thinks this is still 2003 and has no updated this to provide a functional secure method for sending logs.  I realize most SOHO routers are designed to be user friendly and hands off but this is a serious lapse. Just because you can't see it does not mean there is not an issue. I don't sit on top of my logs all day but in that instance when there is an issue I am trying to resolve having access to the logs is critical.While over all the UI is pretty good It is lacking in a lot of areas. The Entire concept of management is choked and the advanced options  do not go far enough to be useful IMO.Over all this is a good router but I think its over hyped.  For this price I would have expected a bit more functionality.

Have about 15+ devices connected to my netgear router.  At peak use we experience some lagging issues intermittently but its not debilitating.Heard the reviews of this router which has the newer wifi 6 and thought it might improve the lag issue at peak use.With only 7 devices connected this thing could not keep up.  Between mutliple before and after internet speed tests on different devices, gameplay tests etc it was obviously, clearly much worse than my previous router.The only positive for those who dont have as much demand as my household does is that it quickly resolves lag issues when they arise... it seems smarter(probably the wifi 6).  But it doesnt keep the lag issues from quickly arising again.

The router was VERY easy to setup with standard configuration as was mine, immediately connect to my iphone 14 pro max, later model ipad pro, and my new ipad mini 6, no issues, HOWEVER, both my smart TV’s - not old models no got streaming or cable channels like fox news, etc…The error was YOUR BROWSER IS NOT SUPPORTED ? So options on TV’s were only two , tried on both , still no go. Wend back to the wifi router, could not resolve there as well…at that point was not going to spend anymore time on this…plugges my old wifi router which i was replacing, 10 years old back up, all was well TV’s came on all was well - one other things was you have no option to use the same router name and password with this unit, at least i could find - so when you change device name / pw, you have to go thru all your devices so they update and work !, RING, RING CHIME EXTENDERS, OTHER CAMERA’S ,  ETC…

Be ready for significant hold times, major language barriers, a severe lack of product knowledge and overall tech knowledge (how could they not know what a WPS button can do on a router in 2024, especially when their routers all have one?!) and advice that will likely worsen the situation you called about! I tried to speak with them twice, and these were my experiences. The settings I was recommended on the first call are still a concern because the security LED light is now turned off, which wasn’t the case after my initial setup. I called back, and that didn’t concern them whatsoever. Nor could they answer my other concerns during the hour-long call. I should have stayed with my old NetGear router that was fine!

reviewTitle: DOES NOT support ipv6 firewall rules.
reviewDescription: I bought this because my Eero crapped out and stopped supporting ipv6 at all a couple weeks ago and I got tired of the lack of control I had over it. To my surprise, this router provides even LESS control! If you are behind a CGNAT and you want to use this router to punch out of it and host things via ipv6; good luck, because you can't. There is no way to configure inbound/outbound rules for the firewall, and even the hacks on the TPLink forums people have come up with do not work. So you're screwed if you want to host anything via ipv6, which I need to do. Basically a waste of money.

reviewTitle: Not good for medium sized house
reviewDescription: This is an OK budget router and works for my home ~1900 sq feet. As soon as I'm in my driveway or garage the signal is noticeably weaker. Also if you have more than 15 devices on your Network, i would get something else. Overall not a bad value for a budget router.

reviewTitle: Great router but died after 3 yr 2 mo
reviewDescription: Worked great while it was working never had an issue after setup, the tether app was very nice to use, router was great but now that I need to replace it because it didn’t last the typical 7-9 years is rather upsetting. Bought April 21 died June 24.
It doesn’t provide enough cover for my 1550 sqft condo. The signal is even worse than the net gear combo, also the speed. If you need something that provides wide coverage, skip this one.
Worked great since 12/2022 then encountered an unrecoverable WAN port unplugged issue (WAN port fried?). Otherwise fine. Seeking a replacement.

So I bought this router back in later 2019 and initially it seemed great. Fast forward to a few days later when my roommate couldn't get some of his apple devices to connect consistently and then random devices got terrible performance.I tweaked some default settings and split the SSIDs for 2.4 and 5GHz bands to see how things went. For a while things were fine, then they were back to the same issues.  I tried smart connect and then oh boy forget about your airplay, Chrome cast, and Amazon smart devices working. Tech support spent about 1 month working with me fixing the issue where devices on the 2.4 and 5GHz bands would just stop communicating (DMZ and AP/SSID Isolation were off BTW). They came out with a fixed firmware after I worked with suppost staff and one of their software R&D engineers over team viewer. This actually fixed the issue but subsequent firmware upgrades haven't helped the device.USB storage used to randomly disconnect (this was thankfully pretty much fixed since about march of 2021). The device is still randomly slow and not just due to interference from neighbors with similarly configured networks on similar bands. It just decides to not load some pages and doesn't seem to work with wi-fi calling properly on T-Mobile, and Verizon. I wanted to like this router because the feature set offered is great but pretty much all of it doesn't work. You turn on a setting/function only to find out the router didn't actually make the change and don't get me started on the firmware GUI. It is awful! Settings and lists for your routing table and device list are spread all over the place. I tried manually making adjustments and use port triggers to get wifi calling working but it just switches back to cellular preferred and when it does randomly work my voice cuts out for call recipients every few seconds. I'm not going to bother reporting this issue to TP-link and wait a month for them to figure it out.I bought this unit because the archer c5400 AC model was highly praised but this thing....They've had 2 years to get the firmware straight and it is still garbage. Just save yourself the headache and get something else.
It sometimes will reach where we are in the house and more times not reach.

reviewTitle: This router is very slow and combines the 2.4 and 5 Ghz into one selection
reviewDescription: The combining of the 2.4 and 5 Ghz options, which you cannot separate, is a very bad design.  The router decides which to use.  I never used the 2.4 with my ISP because it is so slow.  I wish I had returned this router and had I known that I would not be able to select which speed I used I would not have purchased it.
Purchased Sept. 2023 lasted till June 14 2024.  Not even a year.

Very difficult took three tries to get just my modem hooked up which is hard wired into the wireless router I don't understand what the issue is then I got my phone in and then I try to get my Alexa in and that kicked me out of the internet so I was without data again for another hour and a half trying to get the wireless internet to work finally after five or six tries I have the wireless router back working and my cell phone is attached but I can't get the echo dot to attach I've done everything imagining possible it keeps saying I have the wrong password so the echo dot seems to be no good this is your product from Amazon so maybe you should figure out what's going on with this issue ..

I think the product was great in regards to the packaging and visual looks. I was not able to fully test the functionality of the product because of the issues with Comcast. This may be more of a review on how difficult Comcast makes using any hardware other than their own but knowing the process I would need to go through prior to purchase would have helped make my decision not a buy better. I was not able to get this to work correctly.
I think it's reliable and I hope it continues to stay this way. It's been couple of months since I bought it. So far good.
This was a replacement for my old, failed router. The transition was seamless. A little more signal power would be nice but this is adequate.

TP-Link has been my go to for a lot of SOHO products. Great value and performance. Setup was easy. Using the router is seamless. Works great for streaming wireless devices. Handles all of the traffic I have as a family of 4. Gave 4 stars as the security logging and some modern capabilities aren't supported with the device.

With so many antennas you'd think coverage would not be a problem in my 3500sf home, but it was. Even my older routers worked fine. Perhaps the largest issue I had with this router is that it lacks the feature to limit bandwidth per device. You may not need that feature but I did. I ended up going with an ASUS ROG Rapture GT-AX11000 Pro instead which not only meets that feature but has a much better range. Overall, this seems like it would still make a fine router for many.

I upgraded to this from another model that was supposedly able to output the 300 I needed. This one performs perfectly and sometimes puts out over 300 even though that’s all o technically pay for. Nice so far, but a technician warned me these don’t last long.

reviewTitle: Fairly easy setup even for a novice
reviewDescription: Fairly easy to set up a wi-fi network with this router. Depending on your internet speeds it might take a while to get started and fully connected but just download the app on your phone or any cell data connected device and follow the prompts!The signal range is enough for most people, but if you find you need more, a cheap range extender will probably do the trick and be simple to connect with the app for this router.If you just need an updated router for typical home use (web browsing, streaming services, email, etc) then I recommend this one. Save yourself some money without sacrificing performance.
Streaming
The Wi-Fi signal good and covers the entire home. It is very stable and reliable.

The device died 6-months after purchase.They TP-Link initially refused to honor the warranty due to the barcode being unreadable but eventually they arranged for a return and replacement.The way they taped their packaging, the serial number was covered by tape and could not be unwrapped without damaging the serial number / barcode.

I just set this up with my Spectrum modem and used the ethernet connection to my compter to congfigure it. I have to say using this method for me was a breeze. I just followed the simple instructions and had it connected in probably about ten minutes. The performance is not any better than the Sprecturm router as far as the connection speed. The good thing is I can give Spectrum back their router and save the $7 monthly fee for using it. I just hope the TP-Link has no longevity problems.

reviewTitle: Not as fast and strong as advertised
reviewDescription: I bought it to increase my speed to a Gigabit network, however I only get less than half of that and it is slower than my 10 year old router. The signal does not go as far as the old router as well.

reviewTitle: Been through two.  Both problematic.  Web interface is unwieldy.
reviewDescription: ALERT - If you buy this off Amazon, make SURE that the seller is Amazon and not a third party selling their goods through the Amazon site.  If it is not an OFFICIAL Amazon purchase, TPLink will not honor the warranty.  My purchase came through something called "Olive Branch Enterprises" and was initially not accepted for return by TPLink.Giving 3 stars instead of 1 to encourage people to read this.  Too many 1 star reviews are from people who are just inept and cannot follow simple instructions.This has not been a reliable router.  Has good speed and does all the basic things a router should do (port forward, DDNS, etc), but have had two fail on me.  Returned the first on due to a dead ethernet port.  The second one worked for five months but now just shows a spinning blue LED and no internet.  I cannot reach the configuration page via my desktop, and even cannot do a factory reset.  I stick the pin in to press the reset button but the blue LED just continues to spin.  Tech support is clueless about what the spinning LED means.  Very disconcertingThe web interface for configuring the devices uses a pastel blue color scheme which might be difficult to read.  Also, using remote maintenance via my 10" tablet, I cannot access any of the advanced features because the link containing those features does not open into the submenus.In the interests of fairness, TPLink support has given me an RMA for replacing my currently unresponsive router.  I see that many people have given it 5 stars and I wish them well.  However, I have had too many issues with it and, when it comes time to get a new router, I will probably go a different route (no pun intended).

I got this in October 2022, and it was working flawlessly for the entire time we've had it. Randomly, in April 2024, the entire 2.4ghz network seemingly died. The router said it was working fine, but no devices could find that network.This is a huge issue as all our smart plugs ran off of the 2.4ghz network, meaning we couldn't control them anymore. We had an attic/whole-house fan turned on with a smart plug at the time, and the network dying meant that we couldn't turn it off (super hard to reach location), even when temperatures dropped into the 40s F overnight.First thing in the morning we went through the painstaking process of accessing the plug just so we can turn this off manually.2 ENTIRE support sessions later, I am allowed to submit an RMA request. Support was nice enough, but having to do every single troubleshooting step twice was a pain. I will update again with my RMA experience.If the router hadn't broken, it would be an easy 5 stars for me, as it was perfect until recently.

reviewTitle: still only so so range in a small house
reviewDescription: The range is still ony so so

The router is great it does receive the full 2 GB service that I get it just does not put out the full 2 GB service because it does not have cat6 ports therefore it does not meet what I'm looking for in a router had to return to get a different router if you want a router that is capable of putting out faster than 1 GB speed you have to get a business grade router double check to make sure the output matches what the input is this router had me confused at first claims to be able to do 10 GB speed but it does not it only can handle the 1 GB speed output

reviewTitle: TPLink SUPPORT IS CLEARLY WANTING AS SUPPORT, BE PREPARED TO WAIT
reviewDescription: Received the unit 02/14/2023. Installed and began service same day. No problem! Unit failed (WIFI AND INTERNET CONNECTION)  05/22/2023. Contacted TPLink to register the product which was my error. Could not register because TPLink stated the SN was not one of their products. Received notice on 05/24/2023 that product could now be registered. Registered and began the process of obtaining an RMA. Provided all the info requested and was directed to payment necessary for shipping cost. The process provided by TPLink REQUIRED I establish a PayPal account, which I refused to do because of previous experiences with PayPal. TPLink Support informed me to use the CC method (It was what I was attempting to use) and all would be well. Informed them what I was using. TPLink Support then instructed me to use the GUEST method of payment. I sent Screen Shots of each page  of the payment process and there was no GUEST process available, they insisted it existed but could not direct me to it. This led to changing the TYPE OF RMA and issuing a new id for it. I was then able to pay the shipping cost and sent the unit to TPLink on 06/02/2023 and was delivered 06/05/2023 to the TPLink facility. Today, 06/13/2023 a replacement unit was received and that is why I write this. The replacement unit is a refurbished unit, not a problem usually. It has a 90 day warranty. The originally purchased unity has a 2 yr warranty. I have had enough so I write this missive. Electronics fail, no big deal. But from May 22 to June 13 is 22 days by my count and the pettiness of TPLink Support continues. An email has been sent, I await the response, but could not hold back from this tale to be told. TPLink Support is not acceptable to me.06/14/2023 UPDATE: Received email reply about warranty of replacement item. The warranty of the original product is carried onto the replacement item, which is 2yr. This part of problem is solved.

reviewTitle: Does NOT work as VPN client with VPN Providers but good as just a wi-fi router
reviewDescription: This review is about the US version (with firmware version 3.6 ast the time of this writing). This is important because the features of the routers vary wildly depending on the firmware revision and the markets they target (the US version may not have features supported by the Asian version to remain compliant with the local laws, etc).-This does NOT work as a VPN client for VPN service providers like ExpressVPN, NordVPN etc who use OpenVPN, Wireguard, etc.The router DOES connect to the VPN server of the provider but the important thing to note is that it does NOT route any of the network traffic through the VPN tunnel!In simple words, it means that even though you use this router, traffic still goes through the ISP as if the router was not there...- There is full MANUAL for this router. Not even a PDF on the website. You get just a "Quickstart" guide which is also available as a PDF on their site.OLD versions of the manual (for firmware revision v1 from 2020-2021) exist but even these do not exist on the official site but have to be downloaded from 3rd party sites. Of course, they are not relevant to the v3 firware now.There is only an "online" webpage based "manual" which is pretty useless.-There is an online forum and we are supposed to register there and then post our issues there. This is even for features which are supposed to work out of the box!Forums and support should be for edge cases where ADDITIONAL help is required. Not for STANDARD features that the router should be supporting!-There is no KILL SWITCH for the VPN. Although the VPN does not work (as of now) please be aware that without a KILL SWITCH (for cases when the VPN connection drops), all your traffic would get exposed as it would no longer be getting tunneled through the VPN!This is a grave oversight on the part of the developers.-Apart from that, if you are not interested in the VPN features but just want a fast wi-fi router then then is a good choice.But then again, if all you need is a fast router then there is no real need to go for this particular model when there are many others from other vendors with more features!

reviewTitle: Dead in less than a year
reviewDescription: Not sure what happened. Had this since nov 23 and it was fine, now when we have new Internet it wouldn't take the Internet from our modem. Keeps saying theres no Internet when i can run the wire directly from the modem to my pc. Had to buy a different brand of router which was CHEAPER than this one by 20$... And that one works better than this one. You don't know what youll get with this model.

I bought this mainly for the WiFi 6 and the extra Ethernet ports. I was hoping to future-proof my home network but I'm already looking to replace this.It has trend micro built-in, which false flags legitimate services. You can go into the settings to disable the different security "features" but the logs show it's still blocking services even when disabled. There is no option to whitelist services.I run Home Assistant and UnRaid on my network so I assign static IPs to most of my devices. Because the signal isn't strong on this router I bought one of their OneMesh extenders. Devices connected to the extender will connect to static IPs I have set for other devices. This causes those devices to be unable to send and receive data until I reboot the router, reboot the devices, or all of the above. I tried turning off the DHCP server for the extender to allow the router to handle DHCP fully but this caused the extender to drop off into purgatory until I reset it.The software is very fragmented. Some features available on the Android app don't show up in the web ui and vice versa. Naming devices on the app doesn't always transfer over to the web ui so identifying devices becomes a chore. Also, the guest network is not truly isolated from the main network. I can still scan all the devices on my main network from the guest network. There are a lot of bugs present for a device that's nearly $300 (when it was released). For that price you would expect a little more effort on ironing out the kinks. The firmware has not been updated since December of 2021.It seems like most of these companies release a new model every year or two, release one or two firmware updates, and then abandon support altogether. I've had several Linksys, Netgear, and TP-Link routers so far and the story is almost always the same. Right now I'm saving all my pennies up to buy a router that runs pfsense (no WiFi). I need something that gives me better control over my home network and doesn't force me to use shoddy services I can't opt out of. I may be able to use this router as a wireless AP with pfsense. Only time will tell if it's reliable enough for that menial task.
No better range than the 10 year old Netgear AC1900 that it replaced.

This costs me hours of config effort or i would rate it a 4. I've had 35+ yrs in tech! How this gets releases is a mystery to me! If you intend to use this product in Access Point mode be aware it does not work out of the box. Then if you can get it online you will need to upgrade the firmware software. After which an AP mode button will appear. Select it and magically the router sets itself up as an AP and goes to work. Wifi signal is strong.

This is a very nice device that physically sets up quickly and efficiently.  However, it took almost two hours with tech support to get the device to allow access to the internet despite the device showing it was receiving the internet access.  Non of those pieces were in the included materials thus what started as a 15-20 minute project became a frustrating three hour process (had to wait for a call back after the first 75 minutes with tech support).  It's working great now but the frustration of installation was significant.  Product gets a five, tech support a two.

reviewTitle: Router came with a non factory name and password
reviewDescription: Set up this router and couldn't find it in the wifi list under  the TP-link name. Under this name the TP link app couldn't find the router either. Realized that it was appearing as a different router name and I didn't know the password. Had to hard reset the router to get it back to where I could use it. After the hard reset the app found the router and setup went without a hitch. Don't know why the router came already set to another network. Are they sending out returns? It was still in the shrink wrap...
Trouble shooting issue.  Likely sending back.  Should be easier for price.

I've had this router almost a year now.  I bought it to replace my very dated Netgear router to get a better signal throughout the house.  Seemed to work fine the first few months but now it constantly needs to be shut off and rebooted.  I never had to do this with my Netgear.  I'm ready to put my old Netgear back into service or purchase a new Netgear.  I tried all the trouble shooting advice I could find on line and with TP-Link, and the FW is up to date.  I would avoid TP-Link

As far a budget router its does the job. But the user interface is very lacking. It feels like a first year developer just tossed some pages together. The parental controls is missing a lot of stuff. One thing I disliked was that you can only add 8 devices per rule; and no way to setup a rule for everything connected to the router via Wifi.Dynamic DNS is a nice touch but I haven't tested it yet.Range of the unit is pretty darn good; Getting almost full signal about 70 feet away.If you have the money just get the next level one  unless your just looking for something that works and is low cost.

Faulty router and sent the wrong adapter piece .... ended up having to spend extra money to get router to operate... the capabilities of the router is great for multiple devices and operating wifi 6 capabilities.
The 2nd 5g band is not as good as 1st. Weak signal and slower.

The directions for installing are impossible to understand. You have to scan codes and go to oyher sites and write down directions to go back to. If it is such a great product why can’t they make it customer friendly?

reviewTitle: No technical support to help setup
reviewDescription: Just got it today connected to my Arris cable modem. Only work for 5 minutes and my computer show no network: try to connect technical support but there are no phone just chat roomSince I need set this up ASAP so I have to return look for other options.

I'm stoked with this router. I'm in IT and I have projects that require specific functions on a router for my machines to talk to each other correctly. This guy is affordable and offers the granular settings I've been looking for.I also spoke to Paul Dominic Fernando Perreras in support to troubleshoot an odd issue that had only occurred due to my ISP's modem and the interaction was pleasant, helpful and we achieved the result that had been hoped for. Thank you Paul!For the deal, this thing is great. If you've got fiber this will keep up.

This router rockz! The interface is simple. Easy to install. But there are a few things to make note of. Please do not upgrade the firmware as it will disable the wifi for some unknown reason. Also do not change the name of the wifi keep it the same if you want customize just add a few characters at the end example 2G or 5G actually if you want to put virus at the end by all means do it but at the end. Also to have access to the 2G and 5G signal options please uncheck the smart connect option it will separate the wifi signals so that you can change the password for the 2G and 5G signals. All of this notes come from 2 hours with Tech support at TP-Link very knowledgeable...
I was having slow data and connecting problems and then suddenly wifi failure.  This improved connecting speeds and communications between hardware and internet.

reviewTitle: I took the leap of faith
reviewDescription: My Centurylink modem that I owned lost the 5G signal for wi-fi.  I bought the TP-Link AX1800 WiFi 6 Router (Archer AX21) – Dual Band Wireless Internet Router hoping that it would work, that the Wi-Fi 6 was compatible, and that I did not need to be a genius to replace the old modem with this product.  I have to admit that it was pretty easy to install.  What I did not realize is that I would have to change the network setting on all four of my televisions, reset 4 smart plugs and 2 smart switches.  Both iPhones had to be switched to the newly named and installed network as well as my wireless printer.  Overall, I am very pleased and happy to have a new and more versatile modem for our home.

reviewTitle: It is a great router  router
