reviewDescription: I have a question, how can I get in contact with the seller of this router? I have a issue with the router.
Excellent router , easy to setup and install

I had an older version TP-Link router and it was having some problems so I purchased this router. I've been really happy with the purchase. It covers more rooms than my previous router did and works better. I've also been enjoying the user interface using the Tether app. My old one didn't use the app but with this new router, I can just bring up the app and quickly do whatever I want.

reviewTitle: Seems to have better features and product support
reviewDescription: We liked the access control feature

Initially I had issues setting up the router. It takes nearly half a day for router to update. But once it is complete, I did not have any issues and the range is pretty good too with a great signal strength.

With my previous Tplink router, I did not get a good signal at the farthest distance outside, but with this router I can get a good signal. It also works with a new laptop that has the newer security protocols. Also has the new wifi 6, for new devices.
I've been trying for a couple of weeks to get it to work. No joy  :(I'll keep trying but if it doesn't work I'll have to send it back.

My printer's not that old and it's made by a well-known, reliable brand. When I installed the new router, I kept my old network name and password so the printer would hopefully stay online. What I didn't account for was that some devices get tripped up when the security protocol changes, including my MBP.1st critique. I bought this router primarily for the WPA3 security. Problem is, when that's enabled, the onboard software disables the Wifi Protected Setup (WPS) button. I can't connect my printer and also benefit from WPA3. Apparently many printers aren't compatible with WPA3 and mine is one of them, so why isn't there a clear warning about that? But also to completely disable WPS when WPA3 protocol is active baffles me. It's sloppy.2nd critique. The WPS and Wi-Fi toggle are the same button. It is sooooo hard to hold the button for the right amount of time to tell the router to let my printer online without holding it for too long and turning the network off completely. There was plenty of room for another button. Why in the world would anyone merge these together?3rd critique. It's slow. Oh the internet is fast, but accessing 192.168.0.1 to change settings is a headache. Pages are slow to load, and the router hesitates for a long time when applying new settings--long enough that Chrome thinks the page has frozen and asks me what to do.This is the router I bought to replace another TP-Link router that was more expensive, and had exactly the same features except for WPA3. That router was almost double the price of this one (same production year). I don't know what's going on with TP-link but I'm losing confidence in this brand.

reviewTitle: Good performance when used as not instructed.  No Firmware updates for Security reasons.
reviewDescription: I contacted the company over issues with performance.  I had to disable most of the advanced features per recommendations of the company.  No QOS and many other features as this loads up the CPU and performance drops severely.  This design is intended to be places lower that the devices that connect to it instead of on a high surface or near the top of your living space.  The basement would be better for this device to effectively target (Mu-MIMO) the signal to the client device (your phone, tablet, computer, TV).New Malware attacks to routers are a new approach taken by foreign government sponsored hackers for corporate spying and intelligence gathering.  This approach allows the hackers to capture all your traffic and send it to servers in China or Russia.  Once that information is gathered they can extract your banking and payment methods along with other useful personal information.  I contacted TP-Link about this issue and they responded to me by saying that they have no plans to address router malware now or anytime in the future.  So my advice is to sell your TP-Link gear and buy American company hardware not Chinese companies which have no interest in opposing their government's agenda.

I have been a Netgear fan for a long time. Reliable as I never had a single issue with them in decades. However, WiFi 6 interested me so I decided to try out Asus and TPLink. Asus was very unreliable and TPLink Archer AX6000 worked right away. Speeds weren't as advertised with WiFi no matter which band I was on but hey, It was far faster than what I had before so I kept it.Then yesterday happened. WiFi suddenly dropped. Both bands. LAN works perfectly though. I could see it, router says its on via lights and config, however not a single device could connect to it. Power cycled, hard reset, even factory reset the device and nothing seemed to work. Contacted tech support via online chat. Waited almost 30mins to get help (which I'm not complaining about) but then the lady attempting to assist with my issue kept disappearing. After an hour of minor chats and a reset, summed up to a total of 5 mins work of convo and work, we have gotten no where and were worse off than when I started.I asked to get the issue escalated, around 1.5 hours in, to someone who knew something as her knowledge was that of a basic call center searching for the answer in the FAQs section. I was denied, so I disconnected. Poor communication skills as well. Repeating questions on answers I gave multiple times 30mins prior. Literally my Saturday afternoon was wasted and she gets paid to toy with my time. Frustrating to say the least.Needless to say, its been 2 months since I have had this and I'm goin to attempt to get this working without the horrible; if you want to call it support then I'm going back to Netgear or try something else from ASUS if theres no resolution.

Update, unit has now stopped working 4 times in the last month and a half, and the return window has closed since you only have 30 days. Have owned the unit for a month now and it has dropped out needing to be reset twice so far. Already looking to upgrade if I can not get issue fixed.
Not enough for a 1400 square foot house.

Device works well but still might return it just so that this company won’t have my money. I setup my device and it was fine except that it wasn’t getting the internet signal from the modem. Called customer support and they took control of my computer to see if they could find the problem. They said they found the problem and could fix it, but I’d have to pay them a $100 fee. When I said “no, that doesn’t sound right” they reset everything back to factory and hung up. I called a friend in tech to try to get it figured out myself. Turned out I just had an Ethernet cable plugged into the wrong spot.

An outage caused by my Provider, lasted pretty much all day.  In spite of having circuit protection, my high end router was fried it cost me 7/8ths of the bandwidth I normally have! I'm back to using it pending delivery of a newer high end router.As I was in a single home two story under 2500 Square feet and have multiple repeaters around the house, This router dropped connections, even local, direct to router connected.  was total useless for my particular installation.  Gave up after trying to trouble shoot.  Same maker as my higher end router, but it cannot support even one work from home Mom.

reviewTitle: Not plug in ready. This one's going back
reviewDescription: Seems to be powerful. I had it up and running w/i 5 minutes which is great. Using my phone, I logged into it, changed password and was all set. Then everything went down to a crawl.Trying to log in on my MAC was impossible.  I should say that the MAC found the router and did log in to the router, but when I tried to use the internet on my MAC it said it wasn't connected.So I did the chat thing which they recommend.Then I received a call from a "technician" who didn't appear to know anything beyond the basics.After a few minutes with this faux technician I was told they could recommend another "technician" which I would have to pay for  and that's when the fun times stopped.Not sure what the problem is, but  it's a sign that something in the setup for this  router needs to be improved.I only gave it 2 stars because it was working fine on my phone.

I purchased this to replace a 7 year old AirPort Extreme. The setup was easy, and the app was simple to navigate. Throughput was good as long as I was close to the router, at 250+ Mbps. Signal dropped significantly in other rooms and many of my devices that worked perfectly on the AirPort couldn’t connect at all.I doubled down and bought three range extenders from this brand. Again, the setup was simple and I got coverage throughout my house, but speeds dropped down to 40 mbps in mesh mode.I’m reviving my AirPort and returning all of these.

reviewTitle: Doesn't put out the speed it says it will
reviewDescription: I have 2 gig service and the best it has done is 500 Mbps. The signal is strong everywhere in the house. Set up was not easy as I had to have customer service help. They did a nice job helping.

I just got the TP Link Archer AX10000. Let me just say when you have DSL and not a 100% tech savy, the online (prefer talking to a human being… raised old school) help desk person are quite helpful (thanks Bryant Chacon). So, if your initial DSL Modem / router install is not working, you might want to move the Ethernet cable out of the ETH WAN port and move it to ETH Port 1. Now take the other end of the Ethernet connection and plug it into the WAN. Once that’s done, you should have a white light and internet connection. Now, setup and go from there.Just hoping that I get better performance with DSL, because these big time phone internet companies are being too much of scrooges to setup in rural areas to give better service.

reviewTitle: TEETHER  App DOES NOT WORK, couldn't create initial user/pass so had to use comp for initial setup.
reviewDescription: Tried initial installation on the phone app but got stuck, it kept saying "Could not create local Username & Password".  Tried a few times following the direction booklet EXACTLY but still could not create a local Username & Password (administrator account?).  Went on the computer method and created account on first try.  Other than installation hiccup so far this router is giving me max ISP purchase speed with cat8 cables network.  Will be updating to 940mbps ISP speed soon, will update this review then but so far quite happy with this purchase.Initially I bought the TP AX5400 but hesistant and wanted something with longer range and a bit more powerful to have stable & consistent speed so return the ax5400 and bought this ax6000.  Until the Asus GT-AXE16000(the router I really want but my budget is set at ~300) price get a bit cheaper (around $3-400) I will stick with this router.  Loving this router so far, fast and good enough for speed of around 1g.  If your internet speed cap out at around 1gb then this is probably the best value router for your money, definitely not weak at all!  If you internet is higher than 1gb then pick up the Asus GT-AXE16000.

I initially was unable to get the 5 GHz band on my router to show as available.  I contacted support and it was a simple setting change.  I had the issue resolved in less than ten minutes. JANE DENNISE CAIBIGAN ws knowledgable and reached the resolution quickly.

reviewTitle: The signal is not that good...
reviewDescription: I actually have to buy extender to get signal into my office. The whole flat including office is around 150 square meters.
Up and online for 28 days now with no drops. My main complaint has been resolved. This router is used as 2nd router in my network. No complaints to give at this time.

This router worked pretty well for us while we had cable.  The layout and configuration of our condo needed a boost in order for the cable internet to reach all of the rooms.  Since then we've gone wireless and don't use this anymore.
The included instructions and app forgot one key set up step, the wifi password is located under the router.  Once Joey Sonio cleared that up, the rest of the setup was simple.

reviewTitle: Using the AX6000 as a Bridge Client - Issue resolved
reviewDescription: I Specifically purchased the TP-Link Archer AX6000 to act as a WDS Bridge Client to My CenturyLink C4000.  Downloaded and read the AX6000 manual to be sure that it could be configured as I needed.  The AX6000 manual specifically states: (See attached Image) "If you want to bridge this router to an access point: Enable WDS and Select Station Mode".Unpacked, connected to Power, Logged into the AX6000.  Followed the directions up to the "Select Station Mode".My AX6000 HAS NO WDS Mode: Dropdown.  What?  So contacted TP-Link Support via Chat.Several Hours later, no help.  They finally decided to use Email support while they "Consulted with others".I now have 6 hrs invested in this Router and still cannot use it.Waiting on their "Email" to see if they can resolve it.  Will update once we finally find out.Update 06/07/2021: TP-Link support asked it I could "Update my Firmware" and sent me a link to download it and installed it.  The AX6000 rebooted (as expected) after the update.  Went to Set the WDS mode again.  Still no WDS Mode: Dropdown.Logged out and powered down the AX6000.  (Turned it off, removed power, waited 30 seconds, plugged in power, turned it on, waited about 1 minute, logged back in.  Checked again and still no WDS MODE: selection.Last email I sent"For avoidance of doubt:  I could always set the AX6000 to WDS.  What I could not do (and still can’t) is set the WDS Mode: to “Station”.  THERE IS STILL NO DROPDOWN FOR WDS MODE: as shown in your Manual.  Per your documentation, setting the WDS MODE: to “Station” causes the AX6000 to act as a client to the main root router."Waiting for another response from TP-Link.06/07/2021 Response from TP-Link:"Thank you for your kind feedback for the detail information, I am sorry the previous suggestions can’t solve the product problem.To better assist you, I would like to escalate your case to our senior engineer who will help you solve the problem more efficiently. Please kindly note that they will contact you via email within 1 business day."06/09/2021: The issue has been resolved with the help of TP-Link support.  The basic issue was the WiFi Encryption.  The CA4000 (root router) had to be set to WPA/WPA2-Personalto match the AX6000.

I purchased this router to take advantage of my upgraded internet speed. It worked great for a while. Then, a couple of weeks ago, something changed and my Chromebook doesn't like the internet and drops it. It has a strong connection, but no internet. All other devices work fine and connect well. The Chromebook seems to work better if I turn off the Smart Connect feature on the router.Be sure to update the firmware when you receive it as well.Installation and maintenance are a breeze with the Tether app.
A cheaper alternative to paying the internet carrier an equipment fee.
Seems to a better range and speed then everything I had before
Great product and easy to install. The Internet speed is very fast.👍.

If you're not super tech-savvy, then you may need a teenager to help you with set-up.  Some of the instructions aren't as clear as they could be.  But once you get it going it does what it's supposed to, and seems to do it quite well. I live alone and have a PC, smart tv, smartphone, tablet, and gaming console connected (in addition to my work laptop some evenings).  I've never had any issues with speed or connectivity.

I got it and I'm  not very tech savvy but had it hooked up in less than 15 minutes and it works a lot better than spectrum router and save 7 dollars a month not paying spectrum would recommend it to everyone
Everything about this product was so easy to setup and use.  I recommend this product!
Excelente producto, me encanta.
I like the fact that the product is what I ordered and is performing well

Replaced a Motorola and this unit works much better. Using with a Comcast phone modem  NETGEAR CM2050V NIGHTHAWK. Both of these units are making my internet more stable and much faster. Highly recommended for Comcast Xfinity with Voice
Best product and best service. I’m very happy…

I purchased the TP-Link AX1800 router a little less that 2 years ago and got a Wifi 2.4 GHz broadcast issue on the router. After contacting TP-Link support, it appeared to be the 2.4 GHz signal at Channel 11 was blocked by a nearby stronger signal. After switching to Channel 6 per TP-Link support, the issue was resolved. It is really a very good dual band router for home network connections.

Start to finish by instructions. Failing to do that... extended our step up time by an hour. LOTS of googling had to be done. My son was able to get it up and going and it ended up being a good replacement, it just took time!
Router worked as advertised. Plenty of speed and future proof, at least for a while.

reviewTitle: Great product for a second try
reviewDescription: The first product was faulty, returned it, and the second one seem to work just fine. Satisfied with the speed.

I had an old TP-Link system so I decided to stay with the product.  Maybe was a mistake. Took me 3 hours for setup because it could not seem to understand I was getting rid of old unit.  Had to "re" establish my tp account by signing in "new" using hubby's email because old email was attached to old unit. So after that, went to use the "tether" app and ran into same problem as I had an extender that was setup and it wanted a "new" account to continue.  Once I got past this, the signal started strong.  I live in the country but have 2 LOS (line of sight) towers within 1/4 mile of the house, so one of them is bouncing a signal.  When Mbps goes down in strength, it may tell me it has temporarily lost the signal but it turns itself around and bounces back, which was not happening on old unit.  I was never able to reach a tech when I was having problems setting up.  Has one of those services where you have to have a difficult question to get to a real person otherwise the "standard" questions are answered by a computer. Instructions in package are very vague.  There are a few videos on YouTube but not addressing my issues.

reviewTitle: LinkSys was better, but started having issues
reviewDescription: Needed a new router after my LinkSys started screwing up in multiple ways after a few years. One of the things that cost a star is that my mobile phone will lose connectivity at various times often without warning. The only 2 remedies for it are either a prolonged WiFi disconnect via the WiFi button (10-15min), or complete reboot with a 5min shutdown. It will work then.The other thing is that my printer will disconnect from WiFi and I'll have to re-pair it. The longer it sits unused, the higher the probability it will need to be re-paired. It's a pain, but I'm not sure if it completely the router or the printer itself. So it wasn't counted in the star rating. Just an 'honorable mention'. I have 2 ethernet cables (to tv and laptop) that work flawlessly. There's another tv and an iPad that connect wirelessly. That tv experiences occasional higher latency that throws the voice off from the image. But that is due to distance from router, which I'm hoping to be able to address with the LinkSys repurposed as an extender. If I can find it.

Easy setup - had it all working in about an hour.  Only nit that kept this from being a 5-star rating was the access control interface is clunky at best and illogical at worst.I am upgrading from a NetGear, and I love that the access control interface on the NetGear shows not only what devices are approved, but any that have tried to log in and are blocked.  This makes adding new items easy - you wait for the device to try to log into the SSID, then see that it's been blocked, and you click the box next to it, and hit "Allow", and it's in.The TPLink has choice between a Black (disallow) and a White (allow) List.  It requires manual add to the white list, but the add doesn't always workThe only way to get a new item on the white list is to turn access control OFF, let the new device log in, then turn on white list.  Clunky, and not secure.  Make sure to wait at least a minute after turning access control off before logging in a new device, and wait another full minute to allow the new device to show up in your device list.  See attached pix for a better view of this process.Otherwise good coverage and great speed.  My wife had her iPad running a wifi-intensive game while I was surfing on my Android, and we had our TV on streaming NetFlix all at the same time (yes, a modern couple), and nary a glitch or slowdown.  Still need to test coverage to see if it is as good as the NG, but I imagine with the 4 external antennas, it shouldn't be an issue in our small 2-story house.
Seems to work well. only time will tell.

Hate to review tech merchandise because you never know if it will fail you down the line.  That being said, so far, so good.  FWIW it really seems to be running faster than my old router.  Not sure that is even possible but it is quite fast.Not sure what I think about this being a Chinese product.  I don't work for the CIA or FBI so I am not sure why it would even matter.  I certainly hope that if they had some kind of nefarious hidden apps in this thing that the USA would know that and give us a warning.This thing shipped to me really fast and was in good shape.  Hooked it up and used the same settings I had in my last router and everything was seamless.  I have a few items that access the Wi-Fi and they all work perfectly.Main reason I bought this is because I have too many LAN lines for my old router and I had two good switches break down on my and was tired of spending money buying them over and over.  This router has 8 LAN connections and that worked, so I went with this.  Frankly, I tried to buy an Asus first, but after ordering it and having them tell me it was going to arrive the following Monday, I was then noticed that they were going to do even better getting it to me quickly.  Then they said, instead of sending it in May like I agreed to, they would be sending it in April.  ????????  I canceled that order.

reviewTitle: Very good WiFi 6 router at modest price
reviewDescription: Read a couple professional reviews of budget WiFi 6 routers and the TP-Link AX1800 was highly rated for security and speed. Then shopped around for price and read a bunch of user reviews which were mostly very positive. Amazon’s price wasn’t the best until factoring in the 5% with the credit card.I’m fairly tech capable but I had difficulty using the Tether app to complete the setup. Finally accomplished setup by going to the website.I replaced an old Airport Extreme that has worked fine but was way out of date. The TP-Link AX1800 is in a small cottage so range isn’t much of an issue but I note that my devices get a strong connection outside 75+ ft from the router. I did not do before/after speed measurements but there have been no issues streaming TV and using multiple devices simultaneously. Changing the default password was easy online. Connecting iPhones, iPads, a smart TV was likewise easy.If the Tether app setup had gone as smoothly as advertised, this would be a 5 star review.

Seems like a nice unit in terms of wifi signal strength however it intermittently drops connected devices.  Others have also reported this random disconnecting behavior in reviews.  I've tried a number of solutions; I'm a software engineer and understand these technologies well.  The only way I've found to get devices reconnected is to unplug and power-off for about 3 minutes followed by reconnecting ALL devices.  After going through this painful process a number of times (in the first days of ownership), I've opted to return the router.

reviewTitle: dead in 4 months! (great router before that...)
reviewDescription: I was very happy with this new router initially. Doing speed-test from that router to internet - I've seen speeds up to 1.5Gigs!  WiFi was seen over 800Mbs - no problems at all for 5 months. Then it woke up dead one morning, and nothing could get it back to working again.Now, if only tech support could step in and handle it easily, but NOOOO... I spent hours doing all the tests before calling (and much more testing / debugging, actually) - and eventually I gave up and hung up (after half a day calling back and forth with customer service!) VERY bad support and service. And given it worked only 5 months - I'm not sure I should trust this company/router again... Wasted several days, with no improvement in the situation and with no functioning router, unfortunaly.
Took me a day to get it to work with my spectrum modem. Worked great for about 3 weeks then my mbs dropped to 20-80. Sent it back.

Bought this router in 2022 to replace my ISP's hardware, it worked well enough for about six months but since then I have had nothing but issues, requiring me to factory reset 5 times now.  I've done extensive troubleshooting and the hardware itself is bad.  Packet loss, random disconnects over wired and wireless, Firmware updates that break the device completely until you roll back.  Look elsewhere as you'll potentially be dealing with issues that no end user should have to deal with.

I have returned several different makes during the past 6 weeks.  I could not get them to work!  I thought it would be easy!  I thought anyone, even I, could just plug it in and use it!  In the end I had to hire a professional to install a modem and router (we have Breezeline)  and now it works but occasionally it drops the SIGNAL possibly due to a loose wire? Outside?  Or simply the internet provider isn't that great?  B customer service rep, when I finally got one, and the technician (when I finally got one) told me I had to replace the Modem and Router and I would have NO problems.  So I tried and then hired a professional.  When we have a signal we have actually doubled the strength of the wifi signal!  Sadly we are stuck with B as the other Inet providers would charge us the same price for less BPS or MPS or whatever it is called...

reviewTitle: Cnet rated this highly.  I do not agree
reviewDescription: Setup was a real pain.  I  could not connect the Blink cameras to it.  I spent hours trying to figure it out.  I gave up and connected to the old wifi.  I'm not really sure what I gained from this system

You typically get what you pay for and TP-Link proves that.  I should have known better than to buy their router when their smart plugs I have will drop signal and have a clumsy interface.The router seemed to do its job until 5 months latter when the signal went to almost nothing (icon had the dot only).  It never did a very good job of distance strength, i.e. 1500 sf.  Did not notice the strength was declining until one day no device more than 5' away was getting a signal.Called Tech Support and after 45 minutes of "trouble shooting" the rep would not admit that the router had bit the dust.  So I ended the call, went to BBY and purchased a Netgear, plugged it in and worked great!  The RAX30 has great signal strength and a superb user interface that makes TP-Link's look like beginner programming.Terrible company, horrible product!  Buyer beware.

reviewTitle: No ethernet LED, no usage stats on status dashboard, poor traffic prioritization
reviewDescription: Data traffic stats are too buried under three levels of menus/screens.QOS controls are too primitive for many applications. There is are fine-grained customizable QOS based on UDP and TCP ports.The router turns SIP-ALG back on temporarily on every reboot until it processes the SIP-ALG OFF setting. Once ALG is turned off, it should always be off. Some SIP signalling problems remain which may not be possible to resolve with this router.While there is port teaming for LAN ports, there is no corresponding port teaming capability for WAN ports to take advantage of better cable modems.The Archer AX6000 has a badly lacking traffic monitoring and extremely poor traffic prioritization for real-time interactive voice and video applications. Compared to an older Asus router that the Archer AX6000 was supposed to replace, VoIP quality has dropped significantly.AX6000 antennas which cannot be removed or replaced are also a problem compared to other brands with customizable external antennas.AX6000 guest WiFi options are very poor, and far poorer than other TP-Link WiFi gear, such as the EAP245.Range and performance are no better than less expensive and much older WiFi-4 and WiFi-5 routers. Half of the ethernet ports are very difficult to use due to poor placement under a plastic lip. Lack of Ethernet status LEDs is a big problem when diagnosing Ethernet link problems.At least a couple of the LAN ports should have supported 1/2.5/5 Gbps Ethernet. There is no secondary WAN port to attach to a second Internet service provider.TP-Link should have tried much harder to match features of Netgear & AsusLikely to return this router and go for a more expensive Netgear or Asus WiFi-6 router.
Bought last January, and died this May (would power on, but flash lights and reset every minute). Had to replace it.

Update: I contacted Cox about the issue and it was on their end and not the router.Original Review: I recently bought the Archer AX1800 late October, 2023 and about 2 weeks ago the internet started getting disconnected randomly as shown by a red light on the router. The internet usually is off for about 1 minute and then comes back online and the issue happens at random times when I’m using the internet. It usually happens when I am streaming movies or just watching videos like YouTube.

reviewTitle: Finally got fiber internet in the country. Perfect for wifi needs.
reviewDescription: Easy to use, fast wifi.

reviewTitle: This router is amazing! Replaced a wireless AC unit from 2013
reviewDescription: Replaced the AirPort Extreme in my cabin from 2013 with this. Like going from a ford fiesta to a McLaren Spider lol. Connection is rock solid and never drops out. Very impressed with the range!
Has awesome range and speed

reviewTitle: Does exactly what it’s designed to do
reviewDescription: Item works very well- signal reaches all parts of the house!

reviewTitle: You can't mesh this with another AX6000
reviewDescription: I have an existing AX6000 that is great.  Probably one of the best wife 6 routers still.  The issue came when I moved to a new house and my ISP could only bring the fiber by the garage.  Since my home office was in the opposite side of the house, I needed my existing router to be mounted in the garage, and yet have a switch or another router in my home office.  I have a lot of devices that I used the data ports in my existing router to get the best signal.  I thought I could get another AX6000 for my home office to use all of its data ports, and it would also extend my wifi signal.  It did not work since the two AX6000 could not mesh, and when I tried to at least have the second AX6000 to be a an Access Point, it would not work via the wifi.  It would only work if I had a data cable going from router to router.  If you are looking for a great wifi router that is fast and easy on its own, this is your device.  If you are planning to do anything fancy like using two of these devices like the scenario I mentioned above, you are better off just getting some wifi extenders, or run a lot of data cables to have the two routers work well.
This is perfect for my seasonal campground. We have wireless wi-fi and had a different router, which was constantly giving me the wheel of death. Hooked this 1 up and truly works great.

reviewTitle: Great Connection and Easy to Setup
reviewDescription: This was setup in 15 mins, it was so helpful within their app. I have not lost connection on any of my devices and it’s been a few days already. I will forever use TP-Link customer. Thanks for making such a great internet connecting productive.

Set up was fairly easy. Worked immediately with my Verizon FIOS network.  Note: There is a password on a label on the bottom of the router. Write it down IMMEDIATELY (It is so small, I needed a magnifying glass to read it). I first made the connections and then had difficulty accessing it when I needed it.

When I initially set up my WiFi I was using a modem/ router combo (surfboard) to get my signal from my ISP. After setting it up I noticed my upload and download speeds were struggling to live up to the plans standards (80mbps download on a 800mbps plan). I decided to add this on to my existing hardware to hopefully improve the strength and boy did it ever! Setup was a breeze just an ethernet connection and a bit of app setup and I was good to go.The application allows you to view devices are connected to your 2.4ghz network and your 5g network which is great for pinpointing which devices are going to receive the best connection on your 5g network.The performance of the router has been exceptional. My devices that require heavy upload and download speeds have nearly 5x’d their previous speeds (now at around 400mbps download) not to mention I was actually able to change the network names and passwords. Overall a great buy!
Ordered for my son and it was what he wanted

Well Oct 2021 I bought this router. As of today 7/19/23, I don't know if my "connected without internet" problem was the provider's or my issue. Today I broke down and had my provider install their rental router. They discovered I had internet if I connected directly to my computer instead of straight wifi.  This is after 5 days trying to figure out what the probem was.  When I try to get TP-Link help I end up being transferred to "pay" subscription technician. Two stars because I did use for the router almost yearss.
I have had this installed for around a month now, reset multiple times and I was very surprised to see slower speeds than the free router given by spectrum. I will be switching to another router

reviewTitle: UpDated.1/30/2022 Easy set-up. good speed. lose internet & required restart. Problem hasn't recurred
reviewDescription: 1/6/2022 AM I've had this only a few days and have lost internet signal several times, first while initially setting it up and just now, again. During setup, assumed user error and went on but this time it just wasn't working for my cell phone last night and this morning the led was red.  No reason apparent. Restarted the router. Frustrating. Haven't taken time to call tech support yet.1/6/2022 PM Router lost internet connection again and again for a total of 4 times in 12 hours. Called support spent long time with Bot. got nowhere. started chat spent over an hour, told to document next time it fails with screens shots of router reports and email them.1/30/2022 I haven't lost internet signal since to further troubleshoot issue. Tech email said they closed query as I hadn't contacted them again but could use reference no. if the issue arose again.  I have no explanation for first few days of problems. Internet service provider hadn't been reporting any other service interruption problems in my area.

Everything was working fine and all of a sudden the 2.4ghz was very slow. The 5ghz is working fine but a lot of my smart devices rely on 2.4ghz. Their tech support can be very clueless at times as they only know the basics as well.I tried everything and the 2ghz band was only getting 1mpbs, even with a cat 8 cable, reset, changing width and channels, I gave up so am returning it. The firmware is up to date. Anything you can think of, I've tried. This device turned out to be defective after 2 weeks. Might try a different one now.

reviewTitle: Tech support was worse than useless.
reviewDescription: The router seems to be of good quality and looks nice.  It's fairly big but that's ok.  A very nice feature is that it has 8 Gigabit LAN ports.  Setup was straight forward and easy mostly.My problem came with my network attached storage.  The unit could not find it.  However, Window File Explorer could access it so it was on the network and operational.  But, programs that accessed the NAS directly, such as backup software and my Sonos system, could not see it.TP-Link only has chat tech support.  I spent about three hours on chat with them.  Most of the time while they thought about the issue for a long time, consulting/researching, and then came back with another clueless question or suggestion.  The first tech(?) decided he needed help and passed me to another.  Then that person came to the end of her shift and was going to pass me onto another.  I gave up, closed the chat, and am returning the unit.  It was obvious that they had no clue what a router is or how it works.

reviewTitle: Unreliable and ineffective for what is supposed to be a premium wireless router
reviewDescription: Started dropping connection within two months.  Slow speed and poor connection no matter how close or far from the router you were.  Returned to old wireless equipment by three months.  Very disappointed at this pricepoint.
The Chinese tech support were very respectful, but could never resolve my issue. I ended up buying a 15 foot ether cable to go direct instead of wireless... ugh

Ok not saying that it is a Bad product but I live in a One story 2100 square foot house and tried it with two different internet providers Spectrum and Local Internet (Fiber) and did not get internet in the farthest room in the houseStanding in front of the Router worked perfect but as I walked away speed went down considerably to the point where Speedtest was under 100Mbps in the roomOld router worked better so I have to return this one for a refund

reviewTitle: This router did not work with Samsung TV plus channels.
reviewDescription: This router worked fine, but we could not get the Samsung TV plus channels regularly, it was intermittent. We tried everything we could think of. We finally returned to renting a router from internet provider.  Now we have missed the deadline for returning

reviewTitle: Range, Download - YES. Upload Speeds, Continously Signal - NO
reviewDescription: Have this router for three years now, and couldn't figure out why my uploads were abysmal. I was also getting buffering, sudden drops in speed the  back up again.Thought it was the provider (Frontier), had a service guy three times who proved the service was fine.Went to an old Verizon router and problems vanished.Read reviews and seems the upload problem is chronic. Spent a pretty penny on this router and very disappointed it didn't come through on all counts like it should.

reviewTitle: Great speed, software is a step down from 6 years ago
reviewDescription: Speed is great, but the interface is lacking compared to my previous router (TP-Link N450). You can't set a custom domain in the DHCP settings on this one, which is annoying. I might look into installing custom firmware.
very good product

Router achieved good speeds both wired and wirelessly for my 400Mbps service from Comcast/Xfinity in SW FL.  The highest wireless speed measured by Speedtest was 460Mbps which was achieved on my OnePlus8T.  Initially, the highest speed on my HP Laptop containing a RealTek RTL8821CE (802.11ac/abgn capable) was a dismal 8Mbps!  But I discovered that was caused by a default setting on the router - something called "Smart Connect" in the Wireless menu was enabled by default.  When I disabled Smart Connect, I achieved 190Mbps.This router does NOT provide any IP-Filtering!  I wish I had discovered this before my return window.  The lack of this feature substantially reduces the security for my LAN which is under constant attack (mostly from RU addresses).You can login to the router with HTTP (where you will get a security warning) or HTTPS but the latter has to be explicitly enabled and will also produce a warning from your browser that the address isn't trusted. This is because TP Link uses a self-signed certificate whose trust can't be verified; if TP Link would've just paid for a certificate from a trust agent (for a very minimal cost), you wouldn't get this warning. TP-Link's support page considers this low-risk since this connection is on your LAN. TP Link is a Chinese company.

reviewTitle: Beast of a router, slow support, color scheme next to unreadable for colorblind
reviewDescription: Great router, firmware update from a month ago fixed the QOS issues I've read about but never had by giving you the ability to disable it.Range and speed, this is one of the best I've run across.User interface looks like someone said "let's make it like edgy and use red everywhere" - high contrast red on white? Nah man we're going regular red on brown or something - whatever will be hardest to read by a red/green colorblind guy. Yeah...I've had this a couple of months at this point and like every other router I've had in my life other than a Nest Wifi it's been rock solid. I've got no complaints so far, and am using it additionally with an external drive as a NAS of sorts.I did notice it doesn't appear to like two external drives added to it or daisy chained - not sure if that's it or these drives dislike each other.One thing to note that most will never ever consider - if you have a reason to install an external antenna, such as if you have some outdoor cameras or like me have 14 feet of rock in a particular location that needs an antenna 14 feet to the right of the router, you will not be able to connect any standard antenna cable to this due to a non-standard antenna attachment. Just no way to do it.Overall it's great other than the laughable "screw you colorblind people" color scheme.

reviewTitle: Good product with a great value!
reviewDescription: I bought TP-Link AX1800 Dual-Band Wi-Fi 6 Smart Router Archer AX21 in Jan, 2021.  The router generated the Wifi signal 3 times as that of Linksys E1200 with such a bargain price.  It worked great till May 2022 when I could not get any network signal either through wireless or wired ethernet connection.  I contacted TP-Link technical support.  They worked with me to solve the problem, but without success.  They agreed to send me a replacement since they provided 3 years warranty.  I was required to register the product and select the way to receive the replacement (either send back the non-functional router first or get the replacement first - they placed a charge on my credit card until receive the non-functional router).  After that and a week's waiting, I received the refurbished replacement router.  For some reasons, I could not get the router to work.  I contacted the technical support again.  The first tier support person spent over an hour with me to troubleshoot the problem but without success.  They escalated the issue to the senior engineer who reached out to me.  He was really an expert in network area.  After some time of troubleshooting, he identified the problem was caused by a Sysco VoIP phone device which connected to the router.  After I unplug that Sysco VoIP phone device, he was able to make the router work.  The Wifi signal and speed is just as good as the previous one.  I am a happy man again!

Never before had a router with a power switch (it’s a push-button on the back). I presumed that the router had no lights until I saw in the 4-page setup guide that there are 4 lights to check.Once turned  on, I could login to the router but couldn’t access the internet.I called TP-Link tech support and spoke with “Paul” who quickly told me to disconnect power to the router and plug it in again. The internet light came on amber and after a minute or so turned green. Internet access then worked.Thank you Paul!

I got this router to use as 3rd party router to my Starlink router.  It was easy to setup and use.  So far I have no complaints.  I was shipped a “new” router but it came with an SSID titled “Crochet Family” so I only assume it was used.  But I did a hard reset and was able to configure the router to my specifications.

reviewTitle: Good but I returned in favor of the AX55
reviewDescription: A nice modem but for a small amount of money more, I’d invest in the AX55 model by the same manufacturer.

The TP installation is easy to follow.  I wasn't getting the results I needed till I upgraded to 1 Gig internet.  It works much better as I have a semi smart home with Apple Home Kit.  Sometime I would loose signal but, mostly due to my ISP not the router.  My home is under 3K sq. ft. but well insulated so my signal in the garage in the back was a little lacking so I put a TP extender there and problem solved.

reviewTitle: Good speed and range, so-so administration
reviewDescription: I upgraded from a 802.11n router to this Wi-Fi 6 (802.11ax) router. I've been very pleased with the speed and the range of this router.Speed: My Wi-FI 6 devices connect to the router around 1200Mbps. Some of my older devices are connected around 800Mbps. I have no issues with multiple devices streaming HD or 4k video.Range: I live in a smaller space but the signal is strong everywhere. There were a few places with the old router where the signal would drop out. Those spots do not exist with the new routerAdmin interface: The admin interface is OK. The router offers some AV protection (which so far has only blocked a legitimate site...). The AV also does not appear to allow you to manually update nor does it indicate when the AV was updated. I have other AV protection on my devices so I'm not too worried about it. A casual user may think that the AV on the router protects their whole network which is very unlikely to be true. The main issue I have with administration is that you can not set a local domain name. This prevents you from referring to your computers using something like 'computername.mydomain'. I had to switch to using another device for DHCP and DNS to resolve the issue. Most likely that will not impact 99% of users but for someone in IT like me it is annoying.Overall: Very solid on speed and range, just decent administration.PS: The device is physically much larger than I expected so pay attention the the dimensions if size/space is a concern!

UPDATE on 8/14/23: Over the weekend, the router lost power and now will not come back on. I’ve started the return process with TP Link, whose customer service was very responsive, and should get a replacement within a week or 2. Fortunately, I still have my old router that I hope will keep me connected for the short term. However, if I didn’t have that backup, I’d have to directly connect a computer and my tv to the modem and do without WiFi connectivity for however long the replacement takes to make the cross-country trip from California to S.C.! This router worked fine for nearly 9 months … until it didn’t, so I have to change my rating to less than satisfactory. Otherwise, my previous review below is still mostly accurate.I was replacing a 5-year-old NetGear WiFi 5 router that worked great until it started recently and randomly dropping signal to my work and personal computers and was likely at the end of its useful life.Out of the box setup and operation of the AX1800 were very easy with the TP Link app I downloaded to my phone. I followed the directions of powering off my modem, connecting the modem and router via provided ethernet cord, then powering on the modem and router.Once both devices were fully powered, the app guides you through an easy to follow set of steps to get everything connected. All told, it took maybe 15 minutes from opening the box to having a signal to all my devices (hardest part was getting the damn plastic wrap off the antennas!). I have noticeably faster performance with all my devices now with the improved WiFi 6 technology vs. the older WiFi 5.I have a small condo, less than 1,000 sq. ft., with about 8 devices using WiFi, so I'm not in need of the biggest and baddest router that maybe a gamer or multi-person, larger household might want. This one has, so far, worked very well for my needs, and at a very reasonable price of about $70 on sale.One suggestion: This router tends to run hot, especially on the bottom, even though the manufacturer has upgraded the design from the older model to dissipate heat better. I attached some small squares of foam packing to the four bottom corners to raise it off the shelf an inch or so and that seems to help.

I thought this would be a quick install but 6 hrs later I’m still struggling. Connected everything as instructed by the manual. Ran ethernet from the modem to the router, and it was not finding the router. Called spectrum thinking maybe it was an issue on their end, they ended up sending out a technician who could not get it to work either. Technician thinks it’s a faulty router. For $80, it should not be this difficult. We tried hardwiring it with an ethernet cable, as well as the app and nothing worked.

Wi-Fi is no longer working, previously the same stationary devices connected with strong signal.In addition, the Internet/Glove icon green light has never worked, have contacted support via chat on two occasions and have an ongoing conversation with TP-Link's community forum without a solution.I have my heart set on this particular router because my present 7-year-old TP-Link Archer C1900 (C9) has been very good, but I must replace it with a newer one.

I bought this router to broadcast wifi in a band setting to transmit the instruments signals wirelessly. The last two performances it had issues broadcasting wifi. It took a lot of troubleshooting to get it to connect with the instruments. I never had any issues like this with much much older 2.4 Ghz router. So, I'm using my older router again because it's more reliable.

reviewTitle: Good router BUT with a terrible flaw that brings it down to 2 stars. Read more below
reviewDescription: No time wasted, i will procede directly to pros and cons:Pros (with a HUGE *):1. Good 2.4 and 5.0 speed2. Good ethernet speed (1000mbps)3. Good software featuresCons:1. The huge * itself, which is POOR RANGE. Now allow me to elaborate. I was trying to setup an extender which is about 15 meters away, with only a glass door in between and clear line of sight. I go to the extender position and look at the signal strength and WOW 5 bars, almost no signal lost (at least i believed) even in my garage where wifi has never reached i got 1 bar. So theoretically this had GREAT range. But no. As soon as my extender connected, the connection dropped and SSID even dissapeared. That was weird, so i pulled out my cellphone thinking the extender was bad. Same result, got 5 bars signal but as soon as i connected, connection dropped and SSID disappeared. Tested 2 more cellphones, 2 laptops, a Nintendo Switch, all to which gave me the exact same result. I closed in to the router with all devices and with a whole day of testing concluded that the signal could be reliably held with ANY device being 5 meters or closer. Thats right, 5 meters. Then i thought, maybe my house is over a iron ore or something. No, i bout a $20 linksys ac1200 and could easily reach the extender 15m away and even more with a stable and reliable signal. Curious is that at about 20m, this router does "appear" to have more signal strength than the ac1200, but as soon as connection is attempted, connection drops and SSID dissapears.I would have given it 0 stars, but i guess anything in a 5m radius works well. but totally a BAD ROUTER if what you are looking for is range. If all your devices are 5m o nearer then i guess this is good for that.Tried all firmwares on the support page and nothing fixed this issue.

reviewTitle: Has worked great for several years, but no more firmware updates
reviewDescription: This is a HUGE issue because there are known vulnerabilities that seemingly will not get fixed. Last firmware update was June of '23.As I stated, it has worked well for me, but cutting off support, especially firmware updates to address known remote code execution vulnerabilities, is simply a dealbreaker.Very bad look for the company that makes these.

reviewTitle: Blazing fast service... for about 20 feet.
reviewDescription: I had to disconnect and uninstall this hardware after it proved to be SIGNIFICANTLY slower than my 3 year old Spectrum provided router. Tested at many different distances and with many different devices. I could easily watch the signal drop as I simply walked away from the router. I know tp link is usually a good product, and it worked amazingly well as long as I was sitting right next to the router. But that makes this essentially useless. Maybe it was just the one I got.

This was easy to set up and has good software. Ran relatively issue free for a year. Now, out of nowhere, it is broken and can no longer accept Ethernet signal in. I know routers don’t last forever, but I would hope for more than 16 months.

reviewTitle: Claim Of IPv6 Support Is Simply False…
reviewDescription: This router is fine if you’re ok with IPv4 support only. But, TP-Link lists support for IPv6 on this router. One of the primary purposes of implementing IPv6 is to allow host to host communication access the internet without NAT or other hacks that were used in the IPv4 world. This router simply does not support, in any functional way, IPv6, unless you consider LAN only access as functional. I have tried various ways to access a LAN based server from the WAN side using IPv6 addressing and it simply doesn’t work. I opened a ticket with TP-Link, and after numerous non-responsive replies from their support staff, they finally sent a response saying they don’t support IPv6 firewall rules or DMZ or port mapping for IPv6. So, if you want to use IPv6 to access local resources, forget about it. In my case I use StarLink as my ISP and they use CGNAT which does not functionally support IPv4 based access to local resources. But they are supporting (unofficially at this point) IPv6 addressing. But that only “works” functionally of your router doesn’t simply block IPv6 inbound traffic at the firewall, and doesn’t support DMZ or other standard features that it should for IPv6 based routing. THIS ROUTER DOES NOT FUNCTIONALLY SUPPORT IPv6…so be warned. Very dissatisfied with TP-Link on this…

reviewTitle: Probably good, but I got a lemon, and support has been difficult.
reviewDescription: Router worked fine for the first 3 weeks. Then one day it just stopped providing Wi-Fi. I have a technical background and did a significant amount of troubleshooting before trying to work with their customer support. Router would provide Wi-Fi for a minute or two after rebooted but then would drop.Modem is perfectly fine. I am able to get a solid signal with devices hardwired to the modem or if I use an old router. I worked with their customer support for at least 4 hours. That was all to determine that router just may have and unrecoverable fault. The strange thing is if I slave that router off of my old router it will work just fine. It has been providing internet for the last 3 to 4 weeks as a slave to the old router. That is an unacceptable setup as my old router is almost 10 years old. It is certainly not up to date with its security and can't support the number of wireless devices I have around the home.Customer support told me they would provide expedited replacement of the device. That day happened to be a day before their national holiday, I don't know what it was. However, 3 to 4 weeks later, I still don't have a replacement router. I'm disappointed because TP-Link has been a solid brand for me before.At this point I think I will just buy a new Netgear router, and if they ever send me the replacement I will put it in my barn or a closet. Very disappointed in the service I received...*****************UPDATE: I bought a Netgear. Looks like they have drug it out past my replacement window of Oct 6, so we'll see what they do. I requested a refund.
Have a lot more issues with Xfinity service than I do with the router!

reviewTitle: Solved our WiFi issues and then some
reviewDescription: We have been having poor performance from the WiFi router on the equipment provided by our cable internet provider for some time. It was so bad I had to resort to turning off WiFi antenna on my iPhone and use cellular because it would timeout on simplest internet tasks, even with an apparently strong signal and only about 20 feet from the wireless access point.  Calling over WiFi was sometimes of poor quality. The network administration capabilities were very limited as well.The equipment probably at least 8 years old, and while we still need it to connect to the cable, its WiFi is turned off and replaced with the AX1800's.The improvement with the AX1800 is remarkable. Coverage is great throughout our house even for higher bandwidth tasks.Setup was a little tricky because my phone kept reconnecting to the existing WiFi network as I updated settings for the new one.  And it took awhile for me to figure out how to reconnect a few of the smart plugs.Just prior to this I had tried a range extender to fix the coverage and connectivity issues. But it only compounded them. These turned out to be related to the outdated WiFi capabilities of the older router, such as not supporting single SSID for both wireless bands.
Easy setup, works well, allows you to create multiple networks.

reviewTitle: AX21 is a worthy router to cover a house.
reviewDescription: Now I have to say up front I was close to regretting getting the Archer AX21.  I had it up and running in about 5-10 minutes but, for the first 5 days the wifi devices using it were losing their internet connection multiple times a day and the only way to resolve it was to rebooting the modem.  I started to think maybe some of the bad reviews here were true.I started checking settings, reaching out to TP-LINK (great response form them) and to Motorola, for my cable modem/router combo settings.  Turns out I did not have the Motorola device correctly set for WLAN and Bridge mode (note, the AX21 setup even sees another router and suggest placing the other into Bridge mode, it's just that the Motorola modem required another set to configure the WLAN).  Once that was set the router has been up and running and devices working with it for a week now with no issues.  TP-LINK also had me change some of AX21 internet settings, which I first thought may be part of the issue, but since correctly setting the modem I have changed the AX21 settings back and it still works fine.The wifi coverage on the AX21 is great.  My 100yr old house has plaster walls and large central brick chimney.  The cable modem/router is set up in a back room/office but it had weak coverage to the opposite end of the house even with the TP-Link extender I already had.  I ran cabling to place the AX21 in the living room, near the center of the house.  Once set up, the coverage is great.  I like that I was able to change the extender to OneMesh mode and move to another corner of the house to improve outside coverage for some external security cameras and have one wifi ssid throughout;  the dual mode also split out the 2.4ghz (used by the security system) and the 5ghz used by our tablets and phones.  The only wifi version 6 devices we have are our phones and yet on a speed test on all of our wifi devices were able to get the full speed of our cable internet service.  The AX21 and one the one indoor OneMesh extender even covers our entire very large backyard.Note: If I had wanted to keep using the wifi capabilities of my existing modem/router device, I could left the modem in its default settings and set up the AX21 in access point mode, but I would lose the OneMesh capabilities I wanted for a single network with at least one extender, and my older modem combo only had 2.4ghz, so best for me to use the AX21 as a router and it’s full capabilities.I also like the web admin console and the tether app for the degree of control they provide, from features like checking clients connected and reserving IP addresses to little things like being able to schedule device lights off at night.
My son who is a gamer recommended this while visiting at my house and he set it up. No problems. Happy with the value for money.

reviewTitle: Great Router - Eight Ethernet Ports, Great Interface
reviewDescription: I've had the TP-Link AX6000 WiFi 6 Router (Archer AX6000) for about 10 months. It has been great. No problems at all. It gives a strong WiFi signal and has EIGHT Ethernet ports, which I find extremely useful. I have it located at one end of the apartment and I use with a wired connection to aTP-Link TL-WA3001 WiFi 6 AX3000 Wireless Gigabit Access Point at the other end of the apartment. Between the two, I get great signal coverage and great wireless speed even though I'm in a super-crowded signal environment. The router has a very nice feature for displaying the local connections. I use a Netgear Nighthawk AX6 6-Stream AX4300 WiFi 6 Router (RAX45-100NAS) at another location and I like the TP-Link AX6000 much more.

Have used this for a few months now with no issues. Has easy set up. Just plugged it in and since we don't have cable no modem needed. Our landline phone is VOIP and provided by our ISP and works fine with this. This is much faster than the old standard router our ISP provided.My 9 year old Lenovo desktop came with built in wifi N. The wifi started failing so I replaced it with a matching TP Link Archer TX20e wifi 6. That really sped things up. Getting speeds similar to plugging computer directly into the old router with a WAN cable!
We've had this router for a few months now and it has been terrific - no complaints at all.  Configuration is easy with a nice web interface.
Seems to be working fine good signal through out the house, we got this one to replace our WIFI 5, we always use TIPI Link, good stuff, reasonable price!!😄😃
I get better coverage outside around my house with this router.

reviewTitle: Good feature set for the money
reviewDescription: My last 2 home WiFi routers have been TP-Link and so far I'm very happy.  Before this unit I had their tri-band model and was very happy with the performance and feature set in my apartment.  I teach I.T. courses from home and have moved most of my network over to wired instead of wireless for security and that wired still offers the best overall performance.  So when my last unit took a direct lightning strike (gotta love Florida even when you have UPS and surge protectors) I decided to look for something with more switch ports.  Before I'd connected a couple of 5-port switches into a couple of the 4 ports on the old SOHO unit.  But this is never as good as going direct to your main switch.  I LOVE the 8 ports on this new unit.I was concerned that the antenna could only be pointed in one direction but that hasn't been a problem and the coverage is very good for my needs.  I have the unit wall mounted since I was concerned about a cat trying to sleep on the warm top of the unit, which is covered with vent holes.  It still runs nice and cool with about 10-12 devices connected via a mix of wired and wireless.  The administrative setup is best done via a web browser (but they do offer a phone app) and I can do things like MAC reservations in DHCP, and a few features that most home users probably never think about.  Its not a managed switch so I didn't expect high-end security and features, but it is perfect for my home setup.

Wanted to eliminate poor WiFi coverage zone in the back portions of the house; our ISP-provided mesh router just couldn't reach that far, so this router + its companion mesh extender perfectly resolved the issue. Easily set up using the TP Link phone app + the browser web page. Lots of features, but the defaults should do fine for 95% of users.

reviewTitle: Fast and complete signal. Easy to install.
reviewDescription: This router was quick and easy to install and set up. I have a 900 sq ft house and I have fast Wi-Fi in every room. I even have Wi-Fi signal outside. This is a great option if you don’t want to spend a ridiculous amount of money to buy top quality routers.

I have NEVER owned an easier to set-up router in my life! The reviews I read weren't lying. I couldn't be more pleased with it. Super simple to set up - I was up/running in no time at all and without ANY problems! Unbelievable! The speed I get is very quick - no complaints. Handles all my 'stuff' without any problems!  It was such a pleasant experience to set up. Kudos to TP-Link - they did this one right.

I’m not a technical person by any means, but I was using a router that was at least 5 years old. I was way overdue for a new one.I bought this after a long while and a lot of consideration, I am happy that I did.The setup was so easy, in this time of app’s I am super pleased with the app and it truly walked me through the process of getting the network setup in less than 5 minutes, it also has analytics that helps if there is an issue or as I do for checking signal devices on network etc.The speed has really improved in my 3,000 square foot house. It is substantial in quality and sturdiness, rebooting is simple and fast and it sits in a pretty hot area with my other components and there is no issue with the performance.There is a myriad of choices of routers and I am glad that I went with this one
Great coverage in my 4000 square foot shop.  Great signal strength and pretty fast with my internet of a point to point  range extender. Streaming and internet on all electronics with no problems.

reviewTitle: WORKS GREAT WITH ATT FIBER AND HAS 8 PORTS!
reviewDescription: I got this, mainly to I have eight ports but it also reaches way further than the AT&T router. I needed a porch because some of my peripherals did not work well going through switches. With eight ports I did not need to use a switch next to the router. You can either call into AT&T and have them do an IP Passthrough and shut off the AT&T wireless or do it yourself before you hook this router up. You will need to hook this router up through the blue 5 Gb port on your AT&T router. Do not plug the TP Link into one of the regular ports. So you will have the AT&T router hooked like normal to the AT&T modem, and then the TP link will be hooked to the blue port on the AT&T router.
No issues so far. Make sure this and the modem connected to it are both on working surge protectors. Good amount of settings. Standard range. Nothing has problems connecting.

I did not have much time to do my usual investigation into buying a new router but the selling point with this one was that the reviews stated easy installation. Really needing something quickly this was tipping point for me and it delivered. I had it up and running in about 20 minutes. Same day delivery helped, too. I am very satisfied with this purchase.

Bought to use with my wireless ISP service. Didn't need a modem for my service. Packed with modern features like WiFi6, OFDMA, beamforming, and a primary, guest, and IoT network. Tether app works well. Planned to pair with a RE605 range extender but may not even need it since it is so powerful. Low power usage as well. Easy to set up using the Tether app.

reviewTitle: Did not work with Arris SBG8300
reviewDescription: This device failed to connect to the Internet while connected to an Arris Surfboard SBG8300 modem while the Arris was in bridge mode.  I called TP-Link support twice and after the router connected for a few minutes, the second rep had me run a firmware update which then - upon the router rebooting - failed to connect to the modem (the computer has a connection when physically connected to the modem, so it's not the computer and it's not the modem).  I am returning this to Amazon.  TP-Link said, after the second rep was stuck, "We'll email you, then click a link and try to update the firmware that way."  I'm done, I've wasted enough time on this junk, sending it back to Amazon.  I wish it worked because the Arris' built-in Wi-Fi is truly horrible, but I'm not wasting any more of my time on TP-Link.  I'm not rating the Wi-Fi signal since I never got that far in connecting the router and successfully obtaining ethernet for more than five minutes.  (My previous setup was only DOCSIS 3.0, so I am trying to upgrade to 3.1 and it's going poorly.)  Oh, and the operating and error lights are red and green which are difficult to distinguish for those of us cursed with color-blindness; at least Arris uses blue and green.  Minus one star on user interface for TP-Link mocking the color-blind.  When on the phone with tech support I had to ask my wife to state the color of each light (spoiler: red light for Internet connection for no apparent reason).

reviewTitle: Does not have all claimed features
reviewDescription: Router works fine, but latest hardware version removed the VPN Client option. Since that was the primary purpose for buying this router, it has limited use unless I can install third party firmware. Not pleased.

WiFi speeds were decently fast. A little better than TP Link’s AX80. But the Ethernet is trash. I barely could get 600/300 on my gaming device! The QoS and gaming features are just marketing jumble, the router itself couldn’t get close to a gig from the modem! I tried resetting, qos, static IP and nothing improved it. Modem was set up right too.Switching back to the AX80 which gets me 990/960 from the modem and 800/800 to device on Ethernet. I’m not a networking wiz but for some reason the standard router works better even with qos features. I think the only true gaming router out there is asus and that’s because their software actually works. I tried the archer ax10000 in hopes of a little better performance from the AX80 which gets no love from reviewers. Mission failed, but the AX80 outperforms its spec so go with that for $50 less

reviewTitle: It’s good until it stops working
reviewDescription: I bought this in October of last year and now it won’t work. Set up was also not very easy it struggled to connect at first for some reason. Had to redo it 10x till it worked. Didn’t have a problem with it until now (9 months since installation)

reviewTitle: Wifi On/off button does NOT stop wifi signal
reviewDescription: Know that if you are looking for a router that allows you to turn on & off the wifi without powering down the router, this is NOT what you are looking for.  Yes, it has an on/off button and even the lights go out when the wifi is supposedly off, however this does NOT stop the wifi signal - confirmed with an RF meter.Only positive I can say is that it was easy to set-up.

reviewTitle: Upload hard capped to under 490Mbps upload (internal and external)
reviewDescription: First of all I would like to thank TP-Link for creating a magnificent router. However, Whoever decided it would be smart to enable QoS Full time with no way to disable it (thus limiting speed), Bone-headed mistake that is making many people return the otherwise perfect router.Low upload speed is the AX6000High upload speed is my 3 year old damaged AC68ULong version of review:Pros1: Quick UI2: Easy Setup (even for non tech savvy individuals)3: Secure router (forces you to change password on first start)4: Very reliable5: Can enable certain internal IP's / devices as priority over other devices6: SUPER STRONG WIFI SIGNAL compared to about 70 other routers I've had over the years this one is the strongest 5GHz and 2.4GHz signal ever. Even with the antennas folded down to look more sleek.Cons1: Upload speed is capped no matter what I modify or edit in the speed settings for QoS, It's a clear limitation due to poor execution of the company, They blame the ISP yet in the pictures you can see my old router hitting 900Mbps upload consistently. That was done to the same server for speedtest and same IP for my routers. (More details below)2: Fingerprint holding plastic (the oils from your skin stain the glossy plastic)If you have under 500Mbps upload speed from your ISP (and dont mind having slow internal network speeds) Then buying this router will make you happy. But for me, I bought the router to replace my Asus AC68U which the cat's been laying on (frying the silicon) which was originally capable of 1900Mbps throughput but gives me troubles now. (Thanks cat)Had a chat with a TP-Link "Engineer" who blamed the low upload speed on my ISP. Which is completely nonsensical since as you see in the pictures, I'm getting 800/900 with another router on the same connection on the same day with the same configuration. TP-Link fails to accept responsibility so It will never get fixed. That or they know it's a hardware limitation of some kind. Firmware of AX6000 is up to date. All I know is the engineer lied to me. I'm returning the unit.

reviewTitle: When you want it to just work... It doesn't
reviewDescription: As others have stipulated there's something wrong with the implementation of QoS on this router and unfortunately, it can't be disabled.  To make matters worse, tech support is pretty much of no help as they go through their typical checklist which isn’t going to fix the issue.  Because there's something wrong with the routers QoS I have to put it into bridge mode (effectively losing all advanced functionality) just to get it to work right.  It's sad when AT&Ts router works better.In router mode overall DL/UP speeds aren't greatly impacted, however, QoS is messing with the pipelines (i.e. port throttling).  For example, using speedtest I can get respectable DL/UP speeds but browsing the web feels sluggish even when changing the DNS server.  Even then my biggest issue isn’t the sluggish browsing but the fact that some apps are being throttled to a significant degree especially on the upload side.  TP-Link heavily caters to Speedtest but they don’t with TestMy.net.  In router mode over bi-directional gigabit fiber testmy.net results in upload speeds of around 30Mbps - SAD.  Now, take Kik Messenger on my Galaxy S10+ as another example.  For some reason I am unable to upload anything.  Literally everything I try uploading fails.  The moment I switch off Wi-Fi or jump on a different Wi-Fi everything works fine again.  I’ve factory reset this router multiple times and even doing the most basic of setups this exact phenomenon occurs.  Now, for giggles I uninstalled kik from my phone and reinstalled it and even installed it on other devices to make sure it wasn’t just my phone and the same symptom occurs.How do I know the issue is with the router still?  Because the moment I switch over to bridge mode NOTHING is throttled or inhibited anymore. In bridge mode the AT&T router is forced to do all the routing, IP address assignments/routing tables, port forwarding, etc. The TP-Link router functionality is essentially disabled save for the Wi-Fi.  When in bridge mode my phone can connect to the TP-Link router and Kik Messenger works fine – strange huh?  Don’t get me wrong, the range of the Wi-Fi is fantastic.  I can still be connected to Wi-Fi several houses down on the 2.4 GHz band – even at my son’s bus stop.  I’m thrilled I can get 5 GHz throughout my entire house, but… What good is the range if the QoS is making it unusable?  What good is the advanced functionality when I have to put the router in bridge mode?Dear TP-Link, provide the ability to disable QoS.  It’s absolutely garbage….
Quisiera saber por que sale así, encendió, lo configuré y luego quedo así!

The router works fine for every device but the gaming device (PS5).  It is advertised as a gaming router but consistently drops the connection with the PS5.  During troubleshooting I did a quick google search and found that there were consistent complaints with TP-link routers and specifically with the PS5.  I wish I had known this before buying and would definitely not buy another TP-link router for PlayStation gaming.  Our old router never disconnected from the PS5, but did have slower speed.  The speed for this router on every other device is great, but I can't recommend a gaming router that doesn't work well with one of the more popular consoles available.

reviewTitle: Router works average the first two weeks
reviewDescription: Router works average the first two weeks, after that, it has been terrible.  This router keeps disconnecting all the time. No recommend this router at all.

The router I received from Amazon was the TP-Link Archer AX21 version 4.6, which is the latest hardware version.The Archer AX21 is a confusing router. The TP-Link website shows there have been 7 hardware versions of the AX21. That means that the online reviews at various tech web sites will be discussing features that the latest version may or may not have.For example, the CPU/processor in v1 & v2 was a 1.5 GHz QUAD-CORE processor, but v3 & v4 have a 1 GHz DUAL-CORE processor. There was a USB port included in v1, v2, & v3, but not v4.To make matters worse, look up the FCC ID number on the label on the bottom of the AX21. The FCC testing documents refer to this router as the "Archer AX23".It would be less confusing if review sites would specify exactly what version they were testing. It would also be more honest if TP-Link would just change the model name each time they make a major hardware change.Otherwise, I've been running this router for a week and so far my experience has been positive. I did have to update the firmware. It's a great improvement over my old router.

reviewTitle: Excellent router to update your home WiFi
reviewDescription: I purchased a TP-Link AC1750 in 2020 and thought it was time for an upgrade. It just didn't seem to do as well handling the load of Teams calls that I was in every day working from home. We also moved into a home where the easiest way to tap into the ISP with our cable modem was in the basement, and my office is on the second floor. This router seems to handle the requirements of a modern work-from-home space, and boasts a slightly better range. It was also easy to turn my previous router into a repeater to take and boost the signal to reach farther rooms in the house. I definitely plan to duplicate this process every few years if necessary.

Pros:–Nice design and good price on recent sale–Redesigned housing has lots of ventilation slots on top and bottom so overheating should not be an issue.  However, I did elevate mine off the shelf a few inches using a modified metal bin.  After one week, cool to the touch, no overheating issues others have mentioned with the AX20 unit.–The four external high-gain antennae help hardware at the rear of my house maintain a stable wifi signal.  Internet service plan is 500/500 up/down, I’m currently getting 520-585Mbps.  Not everyone should expect an increase in speeds and I’m not certain mine with continue, but you will notice stronger and more stable connections further from the router--I only have internet service with router, stream TV service with Roku Ultra/SlingTV combo, no modem.  If you can’t get the AX21 to operate as your main router, it works equally well as an Access Point to connect multiple pieces of hardware.  Remain flexible, try different configurations if necessary and don’t write a very negative review the AX21 is junk because it isn’t–The TP-Link Tether app was an easy install but it initially had issues until I figured out how to finally configure the AX21, so I cannot comment on what a first, smooth installation looks like.In the end, it’s configured, easy to use and seems stable.  Won’t know until later how the “remote reboot” works.--Firmware updates.
