TP-Link site offers download of firmware version 1.2; AX21 arrived with v1.26; Tether app updated it further to v1.31 released May 21, 2021 (with numerous bug fixes), so make certain you update the firmware, the entire process is an automated download and installation–click “firmware update” nothing intimidating about it.–Both video doorbells went from 80% wifi signal using Frontier router to 100% with AX21–Upgraded to wifi 6 router because I’m building new PC with motherboard and CPU supporting wifi 6 and upgrading ethernet PCIe card with wifi 6.  Contrary to what some say, I future proofed RJ45 cables from CAT 5e to CAT 7 and 8 even though 5e might be usable.–Would definitely purchased this same router again but so impressed, seriously thinking of upgrading to the recently released TP-Link AX55 router.Cons:–During initial setup, connected to the Frontier router as an Access Point, then connected all hardware (cell phone, two video doorbells, two Roku players, tablet, laptop and desktop–they all quickly recognized the Archer AX21.  Most items are connecting on the 5Ghz band while others only compatible at 2.4Ghz also connect–none of my hardware refused to communicate with AX21.  Next, notified Frontier I purchased my own router for their approval.  However, when I finally moved the RJ45 CAT8 cable from the original router’s WAN port to the TP-Link, this device did not connect to the internet.  Tried multiple troubleshooting trips, still nothing.  I’m using the AX21 as an access point, still connects to dual bands, stronger signals/more bars and Excellent versus Good signal strength.  In the end, did not get rid of Frontier router, it’s still the main routing device for the internet signal handing off to AX21, but will continue trying to understand whether I missed something small but important.  In the end, I’m pleased and can live with current configuration.

reviewTitle: Good product but poor setup instructions
reviewDescription: The setup instructions were missing a few steps, like using the default pass on the router bottom and information given was

reviewTitle: Good performing router. Setup hiccup and some doubts EDITED
reviewDescription: Overall I like this router, it's very fast and I'm pleased with its performance. Setup was a longer task than I anticipated due to two problems. First I could not use the Tether app on my phone to set it up. I had problems setting up an account to use the app so I gave up and used my laptop to set up wifi. The second problem was extremely frustrating because I couldn't connect to it using the ID and Password from the bottom of the router. After a lot of trial and error I did a hard reset of the router using a paper clip. The problem was the PASSWORD WAS INCORRECT. After the reset it immediately recognized the original password from the bottom of the router and I was in business. I'm wondering if this router was a returned piece of equipment. I purchased what was believed to be a new router but I have to admit I have some doubt.EDIT: I have seen another review where a customer had the same experience as me with the ID and Password on the router not working without a hard reset. They were sure they were shipped a returned router but paid for a brand new one. After reading their comments I realized my router was set up as someone else's and returned to Amazon. Now I need to go through the process with Amazon to either refund me the difference between *new* and *refurbished* or ship me a verifiable new router. Not happy about that!

Some issues in the beginning when setting up the router when we first got it. Called customer support and Paul Dominic Perreras was extremely helpful in resolving the issue. The issue was the WiFi was not showing up in the WiFi list but I was instructed to factory reset the router which solved the issue.

Minor design problems, consider changing:  If you want to wall mount this router, you can only mount it securely with the little indicator lights on the front side visible from directly above, or directly below.  So might be best to have the little indicator lights on the wide top surface, and have the cables/power coming in from the left or right side.  Also, and most certainly, make the mounting holes on the bottom so they will grip a screw from all directions.

Side note: I actually got this unit about a year and half ago and ultimately had to return it because it kept loosing connection every 30 mins. I tried everything to troubleshoot it: Google, forum, tech support, etc and nothing worked. Ended up returning it for a refund.Skip to a few months ago and I decided to give it another try since it was time to retire my old Archer. Also, this model kept popping up as the best midrange wifi 6 router for its price. Glad I did because I haven't had any issue since setting it up. It was extremely easy too, I even used my old ssid and pw. All my devices connected without problem and best of all, no more device disconnects. I only have a few devices that are wifi 6 while the rest are wifi 4 and it handles everything without issues. Signal is also really good. I have it placed in the corner on the 2nd floor of my home and I get full signal bars everywhere including the garage. I live in a 2000 sqft 3 story townhouse. As mentioned, been working fine since I got it. Moral of the review, if you get a defective unit the first time, try again. Sometimes we get unlucky with a defective unit, but that shouldn't be an indicator that all units are bad, unless it's your 3rd one.

reviewTitle: An ok router, but no access to advanced settings, and an intrusive privacy polity
reviewDescription: 4-3-2023: TP-Link AX1800 WiFi 6 Router (Archer AX21) – Dual Band Wireless Internet Router, Gigabit portsIt is working ok, so far.  Seems fast, and not much trouble setting it up.  The user interface is very basic, and does not offer access to the advanced features like Netgear, or Cisco.  I did download their app for android, but uninstalled the app after reading and dis-agreeing with their privacy policy.  I don't like the idea of my info being shared with 3rd parties, for whatever reason, excepting as required by law, and to facilitate use and support of the product.  Any, more about the router:  I had a Netgear before, which was a very good router, but was one of the Neatgear routes with the huge security flaw that came out a couple years ago.  When I started to get hacked recently, I decided to get a different router.  So far, it has been more secure.  The features are not as rich as the netgear AC 1750, I had previously, and the build does not seem as robust, but it does work. There is only one light for port connections / network instead on a light for each of the 4 ports.  Another thing, the lights are on the front of the router, not the top.  I previously had my router installed with the cables facing out, away from the wall, for easier access.  You can't do that with this one, because the status lights would not be visible that way.  The wi-fi on off switch is a very small button, on the rear of the router, and has combined function of WPA connect button.  The button is depressed for momentary, 1 second to activate the wpa connect feature, or pressed for about 3 seconds to turn wi-fi broadcast and receive on / off.  Overall, it is ok, so far, but I have seen better.  The price was low, for a router that does what it does.  Don't know about reliability over the long haul, yet.  So far, I am not getting hacked, anymore.

I always use TP, but this one (among many of their current line) has a problem where, if the modem in line before it loses it's internet connection and then reconnects, this router won't reconnect until it is power cycled.  Annoying because my ISP has problems out where I'm at.  Other than that it's great.
Does not install easily had to call customer service and still couldn’t get it to work

reviewTitle: Worse features than an old C5400X
reviewDescription: Be warned.  If you buy the AX6000 and upgrade to the most recent firmware (as of May 2023), that most recent firmware REMOVES the traffic monitor feature.  If you go to system/admin/Tools, there is no longer even a tab for traffic monitor so there is no way to monitor traffic.  I suspect they must have found that turning on traffic monitor causeed some problems so they just removed it instead of fixing it.  Worse, if you upgrade to that firmware, there's a note on the site about how you can't downgrade from this version in order to get the feature back.  So now I'm stuck with a router where I can't correlate times of slow internet with high bandwidth, find out which devices are hogging bandwidth, etc.  My advice is don't even bother buying this router until they release a firmware version that reinstated the traffic monitor.

Out the box it gave me the speeds I was paying for. I bought it in May 2023. As right now Feb 3, 2024 I may get 44mb and I pay a lot more speed at 400mb. Don’t waste your time being it’s a lot more affordable but you get what you pay for.!

reviewTitle: Repurposed as wired-only after 6 months of usage
reviewDescription: At the moment this is being used solely as a wired router and my older router is handling the wireless.  YMMV but if you're on the fence about this router:General:1) DDWrt/Tomato/etc are still not available.  You'll be stuck with stock firmware2) I've preferred just about every other stock firmware over this one3) IP filters are a bit lacking.  I miss being able to add "wildcard'd" strings4) Traffic prioritization works well enough5) Maybe i overlooked it but I haven't seen any quick ways to restrict a device on the main network to intranet only and block it from anything incoming/outgoingWireless:1) While still using this for wireless connectivity, the 2.4ghz was far more reliable while 5ghz needed frequent reboots (despite a daily automatic reset).  Keep that in mind for any devices which take more than a minute to switch connections.2) It was not a major problem but if you have a repeater you will need to check the dhcp table to see what's connected it.  Only the repeater itself will show up in the "Connected Devices" view on the main status page.3) Guest networks had frequent drop-outsWired:1) Functioning as a switch, its great.  The extra ports are definitely help but I also feel like a nail gun to put up a picture.2) Internet speed has been consistent around the 980mbps range and around 1.5 with 2 PC's concurrentlyFinal thoughts:I'd say I paid about $150 more than its worth.  I'd personally recommend looking elsewhere and that's exactly what I was I'm about to finish doing

Purchased this in April 2023, stopped working beginning of June. Contacted the company to return and after many emails back and forth proving the item was defective and stopped working, I did receive another brand new unit. But let me explain the process.Contacted them on 6/7- responded day later. All emails took 2 days of back and forth. This series of steps they required took approximately 3 1/2 weeks of responding to tasks they wanted us to do to prove the unit was faulty!!! In the mean time, we bought another unit so we would have internet!Finally, after 3 1/2 weeks (and 14 emails!) we were told to send unit back at OUR expense and they would replace. So yesterday we received the new unit.Whole ordeal in time- 6/7 through 6/29.Absolute pain in the ass process and the return at OUR expense!
Worked for about 2-3 months. Now it won't connect to the internet
A mid tier gaming router from 5 years ago was more stable than this.It's fine for video streaming but nothing high performance that requires low ping.

Worked good for about a month and a half and then the power just stopped wanting to work. I tried different power cables/plugs and even the original one it came with over and over and it just seemed like it stopped working out of the blue 🙂.

reviewTitle: Don't waste your money on the WiFi 6 hype
reviewDescription: I just upgraded my motherboard to a new one with WiFi6 so I thought if I got a WiFi6 router I could get better speed connecting to my Synology NAS Plex server for uploading files. Testing  with the router in the same room literally inches away from my computer antenna and with no other devices on the network the wifi speed never topped 650 mbps. I did an identical test with my existing Netgear Nighthawk. Same WiFi speeds and the Netgear actually outran the AX6000 by at least 15% using a wired ethernet connection.This next part I was aware of when I bought it and was not a factor in the decision to buy. I'm just stating it for those who may not be aware. The AX6000 boasts a 2.5Gbs speed WAN port. That's your internet connection. Who needs that even if it were true? My CenturyLink DSL connection runs at a measly 30 Mbps. Even a Cable One connection only runs at 100 Mbps.Bottom line: If you already have an AC router don't waste your money on this. If you're upgrading from an N class-- don't waste your money on this. There are plenty of AC class routers available that are just as fast and less expensive.And for Pete's sake don't fall for the special "gaming router" crap with the Star Trek design and a dozen antennas. Might as well flush your dollars down the toilet. I imagine the hard core pajama-boy gamers will disagree. Don't care. I'm addressing normal people.

reviewTitle: The range is much worse than my old router
reviewDescription: My old router was having issue where it constantly disconnects and restarts itself. I bought this one as an upgrade as it has wifi 6. I only have 5 devices using wifi and most of the time only 2 devices using the wifi at the same time. My signal from the old router was very good even when i walk outside of my home. However, with this one, my signal bar barely made 2 lines when i walk to another room. Using 2 devices at the same time always result one has ok signal and the other stuttering. I was very disappointed, or i guess i just had a little too much expectation for a newer device to not performing as good as a 5 year old cheap router?

reviewTitle: Great after a headache of a set up
reviewDescription: I always worry about updating technology because as an older individual, technology isn't my thing.  However, after watching videos and looking at reviews I figured surely my husband and I can do this.  Just to be safe, though, I asked a former co-worker who worked in my office's IT department to be "on-call".  So setting the router up with our modem went well, and I downloaded the app on my phone (with my data on) and proceeded to follow the instructions.  All went well until the step where I was to get an email to continue with the set up - the email never came.  I began to get messages that my server wasn't recognized.  So frustrating!  I could have called the company's tech support but thought I'm not going to wait on-line and deal with the frustration of set up "from afar" - been there and done that.  So I called my IT friend who came over and he couldn't understand why my phone couldn't receive an email as he could access the router on his phone.  He then proceeded to set up the router without the use of the app.  We don't have a lot of technology to deal with but the set up of two phones, a TV, two Alexa devices and a Smart Plug was definitely something I doubt I'd have been able to do without assistance.  In hindsight, maybe we just should have rented a router from our cable company - which I'm sure their staff would have installed.  At any rate - won't ever go through this again.  As for how the router works - we've noticed an improvement in speed, less buffering on our TV, and I'm hoping a higher level of security in general than what our aged router was providing.  As I said, like a lot of older people, I'm not a technology guru but can't understand why these things don't set up as easily as a computer or new phone that pretty much set up by themselves with minimal effort on your part.

Update 03/09/2023:My cable company decided to upgrade my internet speed from 200Mbps to 500Mbps and as a result I am now surfing at average of 460Mbps (see pic). It's been over 4 months and the router is still going strong as ever!I've searched and compared many routers, so far the 'Archer AX21' (in my opinion) is best in terms of ease of setup, solid performance with connection speed, security, and last but not least - best bang-for-your-buck! Again, solid connection with my new TP-Link AX1800 for over a month now (since Christmas 2022).Upgraded to this new router for my 'legacy' equipment, as such my 12 year-old Dell XPS 17 (L702x) which was connecting anywhere from 12Mbps-144Mbps (sometimes 300Mbps) utilizing an old Apple Airport Extreme 5th Gen router, but now I'm connecting at 867Mbps with the TP-Link! Fast? Yes. Though my current ISP plan only offers 200Mbps so I've got plenty of room to expand.Speedtest showed on average 350-370Mbps connection speed in accordance with the Intel 7260ac WiFi card in my Dell XPS 17 so I'm super happy. Others such as my Apple devices are also connected within speeds. I run dual-band setup on the TP-Link so it can allocate whichever band needed automatically by switching both the 2.4 and 5GHz back and forth for best bandwidth and/or least congestion to  establish a stable connection. In order to do this you'll need to enable 'Smart Connect' from the TP-Link tether app or browser setup, otherwise you'll only be connecting to one - either 2.4 or 5GHz. I also love how you can monitor every equipment that is connected to your network - complete with name, duration and band/speed.  Sometimes I do get switched to the 2.4GHz band with speeds of less than 12Mbps but it usually finds itself switching back to higher speeds fairly quickly - which my Airport Extreme fails to do most of the time unless I do a hard reset.That said, this is an exceptional router for the money - it covers dual bands, WiFi 6 capability and the newer WPA3 security feature. Money well spent for many years to come and I do highly recommend the TP-Link.

Easy enough to set up.  I'm in a single level apartment, but I feel it lacks signal strength to keep up with the second TV (streaming) in the bedroom.  [The unit is at one end of a hallway, and the TV is near the door at the other end of the hall].

reviewTitle: Set up was funky but so far so good
reviewDescription: You have to use a cell phone to set it up but once that is done it seems good. Works well in my 3500sqft shop

Setup was a breeze. Took almost 5 minutes. Interface is simple and intuitive. And it's one third the price of a Netgear router. I've been purchasing routers for my company for about 20 years now. I've purchased quite a few.WiFi range is sometimes an issue. I don't see any difference in range with this one compared to the Nighthawk it replaced.I would recommend this router.

It's a good router. It does the job that it is intended for. The only major drawback is you can't do anything locally. You need the router connected to the internet, and you need to setup an account to get into the router to make changes if something goes wrong.This seems to be the thing with modern routers these days. For a budget router, with Gb ethernet and decent 2 band WiFi coverage, you won't be disappointed.

reviewTitle: Good router but not so good as an access point
reviewDescription: I got this router to use as a access point and plan on getting a better more functional router from tp-link to add to my network. But when you use this router as an access point in access point mode the guest Wi-Fi is not isolated it is only isolated when used as a router.

reviewTitle: No great for phones or ipad
reviewDescription: It does not give us great coverage on my phone or iPad, works well for our computer and television
We had trouble with the modem when we first bought it. Customer service, and specifically Carlo was very helpful in troubleshooting the issue. Thank you, Carlo!

It was easy to setup physically but a little tough to get it connected. But I was able to do it. It works great other then that. Just need to update my router because my other on was like 10 years old. So over all I'm happy.

It is not my main router. I used it as a secondary AP, via Ethernet adapter kit. My Main router is an Asus GT-AX11000 which is a monster.This one has some serious capabilities and settings. You on a budget or need a 2nd AP mode router? This is AWESOME!Just make sure to hit up their website and do a Firmware update. The one I received was woefully outdated. mSolved many bugs and unlocked a lot of the features.
WORKS AS IT SHOULD
Great price.  Great product. I have a 250 SQ feet. And it’s does it job. No lagging. We have PS5 TV computer ect. And it works with all of our connections.
Easy to install and set up.
I've had no dead Zones in my 2200 sq ft house, even coverage in the basement.

The Archer was an upgrade from an earlier model, and I have had it for nearly one year. It has worked well with both personal and professional use. I highly recommend this brand. Also, the tech support is responsive, efficient, and superior overall.

I had a supplied router from my internet provider and the speeds were great as long as you were close to the router, the WiFi speed would drop significantly as you got distance between the router and the device. This TP-Link router provides excellent coverage and speeds throughout my entire house. Really wish I would have purchased this years ago.
The speed! Customer service is amazing!
We have about 20 things connected to this device and everything works much better than the router from Verizon.

reviewTitle: Works great. Has a good range.
reviewDescription: Easy set up.

*Updated* After two full weeks of use I gave up on this product. Speeds we're all over the place ranging from 20mbps to over 500mbps. I plugged in my old TP-Link router to make sure it wasn't the modem, and the modem is not the issue. Others have reported connectivity and spend consistency issues in other reviews.  Buyer beware!*Original* Install was a pain as some of the directions were not clear (I had to use Google to change some of the settings I needed to customize) and there was a connectivity issue at first.  I'm wondering if that was due to not logging into my old TP-Link router settings and deleting off the previous router's MAC address. If so, then either the installation information in the box or in the settings menu should warn you ahead of time.That said, once I got things up and running, WiFi speeds went from about 125bps to over 500mbps. I'm on a 900mbps plan, but due to where I live, the shared bandwidth in my neighborhood reduces that speed, which can happen.If you're upgrading from an old router and/or not very tech savvy, then I can see how install would be a challenge.Five stars once you get it up and running.  Four stars because setup takes WAY longer than it should.
Works when it works, but requires constant restarting for reconnection

reviewTitle: works good when its not cutting in and out
reviewDescription: works good when its not cutting in and out

After getting Comcast's gigabit internet, I wanted to upgrade to an AX router for our 2,100 sf single-floor condo. This was the second AX router, of three, that I tried. It was easy to install, had reliable uptime, and put out a nice strong signal in pretty much every corner of our home. There were three problems, though. The first was that I could not - for some reason - get good wireless speeds out of this unit. Holding my iPhone 11 just a couple feet from the router, I maxed out at around 600 Mbs at the most, and in normal use would generally see around 250 to 300 Mbs. That's for a WiFi 6 client, with the wired speed at the modem testing 930 Mbs+. Router speeds seem to really vary based on your individual situation, so YMMV, but that was my experience.  Second, for some reason this unit was really squirrelly when I tried to attach USB hard drives - they would show up in the router interface just fine, would mount on my MacBook Pro, but then would hang when I tried to actually read or write data. USB flash drives would work fine, though. Could be an issue with power at the USB ports, not sure, but the drives I tried all worked fine with my laptop. Finally, and this is the really weird one, my 2-year old HP wireless printer would not work on 2.4 Ghz. It would connect to the network just fine, with a 5-bar signal, but none of my devices could see it, even after going through every network troubleshooting step under the sun. It wouldn't even work via AirPrint with Apple devices - they simply couldn't see the printer even though they were connected to the same network.One problem I can deal with but not three, so had to return it.  That's why I buy from Amazon. It seems that Routers capable of truly handling gigabit wireless speeds are still kind of inconsistent at this point, and you may need to just try a few before you find one that works for your particular situation. Now I'm on the Netgear RAX120, which seems to be working much better for me - at least after 24 hours. We'll see.

reviewTitle: Works only fair but has short range
reviewDescription: Having used TP’s products for years I selected this router to replace a failed unit.  Installation was easy.  Much to my surprise the WIFI range was about 40% less than my previous brand.  I added an extender and while it helped with signal penetration latency increased dramatically.  The technical support is so poor they get lost in in their own instructions.UPDATE:  day 3 everything buffering despite my 1000 speed fiber connection.  The only thing that changed is the router 😩.  The extenders help with signal but add latency beyond what is an acceptable lag, even on their own TPLink switches and plugs.

reviewTitle: Awful if parental conteol is used
reviewDescription: As an everyday use router it works great. If you try using the parental control, neither the parental control ir the router will work.properly.  It will block all the  wifi signal instead of just the ones you want blockes.

reviewTitle: Times out and messes with company VPN
reviewDescription: I work from home, and this router is periodically dropping signal and disconnecting from my company's vpn. It's not messing with streaming or anything else, but that millisecond disconnect is aggravating. Wouldn't recommend if you connect to secure vpn regularly.

reviewTitle: Almost impossible to connect to router
reviewDescription: Followed the instructions given.  Nothing works like they say.  Cannot get it to hook up to PC whatsoever.  It needs a "network key" to connect and they do not provide one.  No tech support available.  Typical modern crap.  You need a tech guru to come install if you're going to make the pos work. I finally got it working by borrowing an older laptop with an ethernet connection to hardwire to the router.  Found they set a network key that was some random number noone would be able to guess, unlike the good old days when they set a default of "admin" as a password.  Why they can't give you the key is a real mystery!

I really like the design and speed of this router. I was hoping for the best but it just wouldn't work for work applications. Me and my fiance work from home and this router creates packet loss issues with VPN clients such as Citrix, Cisco and a VPN router connection to our work. Additionally, it causes problems with zoom and teams meetings where they cut out constantly due to packet loss causing major problems when you're in the middle of a work meeting.I tried contacting TP-Link support but they were very slow to answer questions, making it impossible for me to keep the router even though I was hoping they would have it fix.Base design and good for gaming but I would recommend against if you have a work environment where you have to connect via a VPN portal/ secured network.

Not a terrible choice, however it only lasts a few months. I bought this back in January and the router has already gone bad. I would recommend using a different brand. I'll give the benefit of the doubt and say that I got a faulty router, but just play it safe and get a better/more known brand.

I found the performance of this router to be sorely lacking, both in signal strength and in its handling of the signal saturation in my neighborhood, including 5GHz.  I would have punchy performance frequently unless I configured it to use only channel 165 at 20MHz bandwidth.  Not ideal.  I also experienced quite a bit of interference on bluetooth from this router.I have since purchased an ASUS RT-AX58U refurb from Amazon, and I can't believe the difference.  Plus the ASUS supports DFS channels, giving it up to twice as many channel options.  Nobody in my neighborhood is using those frequencies.  Even when it does choose a frequency a neighbor is using, I have no issues.  AND, if you enable bluetooth co-existence, it seems to have alleviated interference.This was my second TP-Link, and both were sorely disappointing.  The A7 is a trainwreck, this one is slightly better.  I would tell everyone to stay away from these.

I have read many reviews that talk about how easy this is to set up.Not for me!  This is my 3rd or 4th router and I have never experienced the difficulties that I have with this router.  Very close to sending it back but will try one more time.  Issues are many but mainly passwords and app ability to reset passwords .  I am currently locked out for 2 hours due to passwords .  BS

reviewTitle: Have to enter uer name and password for evefry device every time I use it
reviewDescription: I got this because my Linksys router caused buffering all the time on my tv. I installed it but it seems every time I turn on the tv I have to reenter user name and password. Annoying.

reviewTitle: Firmware was old and would not update over web or after downloading
reviewDescription: This router came with older firmware and the setup recommend updating it.  Unlike previous TPLink routers I've owned though, every attempt ended up in failure, including after downloading the firmware and using the local update option.Moreover, I bought it with the hopes of improving the wifi around the house.  But it was not only worse than my existing TPLink router, it would not work with one of the two TPLink extenders (the 600 model), which never would recognize it.  The older 300 model worked.I called support and after a very long wait, they weren't much help.Returned it.

While this router gets a good signal in the room it is placed in I barely get a signal anywhere else, especially on my phone. Once I am more than 25 feet or so I can’t even pick up the router. I got this to use with Ting internet that sends up to 1 gig speeds and when I’m in the majority of my house I can’t even pick up a signal. I highly recommend NOT BUYING this router if you need to cover more than a few hundred feet as it doesn’t even come close to covering a 2,000 square foot house. Very disappointed and will be returning.

reviewTitle: Good basic router, but very limited
reviewDescription: This is an adequate router, but the user interface is inadequate. I don't like the fact that there is no adjustment for DHCP lease time, and the logging features are worse than pitiful. For example, I woke up this morning to find that some of my IoT devices weren't working. The router can tell me that its Internet connection has been up for about 3 hours, but I cannot tell whether it rebooted or whether the Internet connection went down for some reason -- nor how long the connection was down, if that was the problem. There is no available record of when I logged in, or much of anything else.

reviewTitle: Poor signal.  Automatically went to 5 Ghz.
reviewDescription: I compared internet speed between the old TP Link dual band and this one.  My old router is faster on my five computers by about 100 MB (Even the best VPN will slow this down to about 30 to 60 Mb).  I also have devices that require 2.4 Ghz, but this router automatically assigns the band to 5 Ghz and my device doesn't work. It works fine on my old router where I have a different password for each band, forcing it to use the 2.4 Ghz band.  I returned this new router and went back to my old TP Link router.  New isn't better or faster.  It's not hard to have a different password for each band.  The single-password dual band TP Link WiFi6 auto-assignment is a poor feature to have.  I couldn't find any feature that was an improvement over my old router.  This is a dud.

reviewTitle: One thing after another with this thing
reviewDescription: Idk what's going on, but I set it up and at first it was providing wifi for some but not all devices so I switched modes and that managed to work for like a day. once I got all of my things connected I tested it for a day and it was working beautifully the very next day I can barely get ANYTHING to load at a descent speed...I'm down to changing channels to see if this fixes the issue but it isn't the need for a wifi extender as everything is located in the same room 🙄 this device is FRUSTRATING.

I've not had this router for a week and I'm already having problems with my devices losing connection through the wifi signal.  I've chatted with support and this morning I had to factory reset the router and then try to reconnect my devices.  It's really frustrating when your device says "I'm having trouble connecting to the internet" after you've just spent $300 on a shiny new router that is supposed to be better than the 8 year old router it replaced.To update:  I've reset to factory settings and updated the firmware and started over with the set up.  All my laptops, doorbell, Alexa ...everything wifi had to be set up again and it was a bit of a pain after just doing it but it seems to be ok since then.  I lost a bit of trust on it after the hiccup at the start but if this works after resetting it then it will get  a thumbs up with me.  I have a lot of devices that depend on a working wifi router.  My 8 year old router is the backup in case things go wrong.

reviewTitle: Couldn't handle a 46 device small smarthouse
reviewDescription: Unlike my previous two modems this unit came close to handling the large number of devices (46). But not close enough. Unfortunately, after about a week we started experiencing minor dropouts where smart lights would not turn off etc. The router would usually recover, but sometimes we would need to turn the lights off and on. Rebooting the router would help only a little. But I didn't spend the money for a high end router to get one that only sort of fit my needs. So it was returned. A smart house needs 100% stability and signal. You don't want to be worrying if your voice command was going to work or not. It just needs to work. Having said that, it did match my wired ethernet for data speed. If you don't have as many devices, you'll probably be fine with this unit. But if you are trying to avoid a mesh system and want an all in one unit for a smart home, this might not be for you.

reviewTitle: Left with more questions than answers
reviewDescription: This could change but for now—wow—crazy hard to install and crazy harder to get information. Looking to have a website that you can access (let's say you want o to block certain sites) and cannot find it, not sure how it magically hot installed without and email address. AND, trying to get this information will leave you bewildered.

reviewTitle: Archer AX6000 kicks butt, with two huge exceptions
reviewDescription: Just got the AX6000 to be our gigabit FIOS router and it's fast and simple to set up with the browser interface.  Only two surprises and you need to know... This router (and I've learned many other TP-Link "routers") do not provide any local DNS.  If you don't know what this means, then don't worry - you'll love it.  If  you do know what this means, you'll probably want to buy a Raspberry Pi and install Pi-Hole, or maybe just DNSMasq. :)The second surprise is that you will be lucky if you can write to any USB drive inserted in the USB slot.  It only supports SMB 1, which has been deprecated for security reasons by the major software vendors (Microsoft, Apple, Ubuntu).  On Ubuntu, you'll be able to mount it as an ftp drive, but that's not much help if you're hoping to store information from an IoT device with no visible operating system.  Google "TP-Link cannot write to USB" and prepare to be disappointed.I know I am.
Bought one last year, loved it. When lightning took it out, I went to Amazon and hit buy again.Same model number, NOT the same product!!!TP-Link's fault, not Amazon's.

EMAIL I SENT TP-LINK:  Initially, I very much appreciated your follow-up that occurred when I had an unpleasant series of events following the failure of my router.  But my initial pleasant reaction to your unexpected (and much appreciated) overtures regarding my situation have been completely undone.I'm sure TP-Link designs and builds fine devices.  But from time-to-time electronic devices have issues .... thankfully not often.  Also, countless people don't have a clue about what is happening with their devices and ask for replacement or compensation when a simple tweak fixes the perceived problem.  I understand you need a process to separate the wheat from the chaff.That said, it is clear to me that TP-Link customer service policies are woefully inadequate.  I find your customer service approach not only inadequate, but distasteful.  Basically, you teased me then reneged ... that's distasteful.  And then to offer me two light bulbs is preposterous.Other people need to know about my experience (including your offer for two light bulbs) so 1) that they are well aware of what they might experience if their TP-Link devices fails, and 2) maybe, just maybe, your senior customer service people will reevaluate how you treat your customers who have had issues.You can do way better ... that's for sure.

This router sucks, it's not even a remotely better router than the default one Spectrum gave me a year ago. I would routinely have just under 500 mega download. I'm lucky if I get over 400 now. And when someone else get on their device the service gets worse

Been a fan of this company enough to buy two of these for my home. The install was flawless. The design is beautiful with good tight ports on back and clear indicator lights up front. Unfortunately I am having connection issues with both of them as the access will disconnect for just the blink of an eye but that blink is enough to cause issues with my equipment. I will more then likely be replacing with better models as I thought replacing with top of the line cat 8 cable would fix it and it didn't

Wifi signal is very weak. Router is about 20ft of open air away from my PC and the wifi is occasionally spotty but always relatively slow. When I plug in ethernet it is 100% reliable and I get a consistent speed approaching what my ISP claims I'll get. This is about 50MB/s compared to 4-11MB/s that I get over wifi. You shouldn't pay this much for a wireless access point that will frequently be 10x slower than ethernet and never more than 1/4 the speed of ethernet.

reviewTitle: I think their speed are a little exaggerated
reviewDescription: Maybe it’s an issue with my router but I can’t get over 140 Mbps on 2.4, it’s advertised to be at least 547. I know my devices can support these speeds cause when I connect to 5GHz I get over 500mbps (still not 1g speeds either). I’ve tested on multiple devices as well with the same results. QoS is disabled, reboot router, factory reset router, not sure what else to do but at this point I can only give 2 stars for this issue.

reviewTitle: Not compatible with my Comcast approved high speed modem?
reviewDescription: Never got internet with this router. My modem an hour before worked fine with older TP Link router but together, this model and my brand new high speed modem did not seem to work together. Turned things on in the 'order of instructions'--baloney. Comcast support with restarts after modem was knocked off connectivity for 2 hrs; TP Link tried for an hour. No--cloning Mac address is too much and I dont have a Windows machine to do it. Sent this router back. Im not a network engineer who wants to reconfigure a tested consumer product. Im sure a more knowledgeable network consumer could have made this work. Im a business person and want tech products that are user friendly. The Tether app is fine, but the set up instructions DO NOT HELP, they are oversimplified.

reviewTitle: Strong Signal/Doesn’t Play Well With Devices and Alexa Devices
reviewDescription: Bought this router to replace a tried and true Apple Airport extreme. Also added two extenders. Using TP Links “One Mesh System.”Upsides: Incredible reach and strength. Getting supper fast speeds in places we never expected. Easy to add a network USB drive. More LAN ports than others.Downside: Doesn’t work as well with small devices likes plugs and water sensors. For no reason, light switches and devices will not work, internet will stall. And then work again a day later. Resetting all routers and extenders usually helps. I suspect the problem is with the Smart Connect feature which I’ve tried turning on and off. But this is a case of a router being too smart for its own good. If you want a no hassle router, not sure this is it.  And their support pages/forums are super hard to navigate by product.UPDATE: dropped this router down a star. This just doesn't like Alexa. Multi Room speakers are out of sync, etcUPDATE 1/3/23 - I'm now looking for a different router. My apple airport extreme was never this much trouble.

reviewTitle: Works Well with apartment MduNetech Wifi company.
reviewDescription: Works well, just the range could be a bit better. And also the speed is picking up like 20-25megs lowers on the download speeds, and 2-5 megs lower on the upload. Then what I am paying for. But I may just need to tweak the settings. Overall great product.

Had this router for a while now works great came across a weird issue. Resolved by one Bryant Chacon through tp links chat with live service rep feature on their website. It's great to have a feature like this that allows you to quickly connect with professionals willing to help
Was pretty easy to set up and install.

reviewTitle: You MUST register the product in order to connect
reviewDescription: The router was easy to install, had good instructions and has worked well. I put it into a 30' x 50' metal building and get strong signal throughout. I have been using it for about 10 days with no loss of signal or any outages. My one and only complaint is that you must register this product in order for it to work. It tells you that in the instructions. I tried using it without registering and it would not connect to the internet. I don't like companies making me give them my personal information. That should be my choice. I'm sure I'll be seeing an increase in my the junk e-mail soon. I knocked the rating down one star because of this.

I've seen several reviews about the app and what not. I have been debating on whether or not to buy a router. After almost 4 years of dealing with the garbage routers that spectrum supplies, I decided to go ahead and spend the $100. This thing was super simple to set up. Downloaded the app and it walks you through step by step. Out of the box, up and running was 15 minutes. Not one connectivity issue with any of my devices. Ran a speed test and it's up 75 Mbps per second in my upstairs bedroom, which is where my problem was to begin with. Longevity, of course can't speak of, but after 3 days, it's much better than what I had before. Finally! The internet has come to my bedroom!

reviewTitle: Had to get my provider to set up.
reviewDescription: It was too hard to set up. Had to pay for professional to do it. Every thing works but lose signal at times on my older iPads My older iPhone gets one bar or maybe two bars of service while wireless. My daughter says all her newer things work great. As long as she’s happy, I will deal with it.

reviewTitle: I live in the rural woods, the signal fails me at times.
reviewDescription: Wy Fy use age

reviewTitle: Setup is okay but does NOT work as a repeater.
reviewDescription: Needed a repeater.  Was under the impression this could be a wireless access point.  It can, but it has to be hardwired to the router apparently.  Kinda dumb.  Setup wasn’t too bad but spent an hour searching for instructions just to find out in a forum this particular model cannot be a wireless repeater.  Oh well.  It’s likely a good base unit router and WiFi.  And apparently you can buy its extenders to create a “mesh” network.

Replaced my old router and this one was simple to set up. It works well.Update 45 days later: the signal will randomly decrease and make it difficult to work on my computer. If I go wiggle the antennas around a bit it will go back to full signal. It happened for a few weeks and now it's been stable for a while. Hoping it will stay that way.

Archer AX21 1800 dual band Router is suitable for home and small office environments, providing stable and reliable wireless connections that meet daily demands. Whether you are surfing the web, streaming videos at home, or carrying out basic network activities in an office.

I would give the hardware a 5-star rating and the software management a 3 1/2 star rating.  This is my 8th or 9th router over the past 20 years.  I have upgraded as download speeds have increased and firewalls got faster. The install program defaults to an ip address of 192.168.0.x instead of 192.168.1.x.  I had for every previous router.  This causes a problem with fixed ip addresses in my system (NAS, cameras, pcs).  There is an option to correct the ip address after it is installed and to access the wired devices.  The second concern is the channels that are defaulted for 2.4 and 5.0 GHz bands.  The house lots in my neighborhood are large (3/4 acre and up).  On my laptop there are 21 WAPs showing in my home. To determine the best channels to set the wifi to I use inSSIDer software (there are several others)  on the laptop to measure the signal level at different locations in my home.  I was able to set the channels to minimize outside WAP interference.  FWIW the 2.4GHz channel only has 1,6,&11 as clear channels and Cisco/Linksys default to channel 6.  My next neighbor is using channel 11 so I can only use 1 for a camera.

reviewTitle: Started to have issues after 1 year
reviewDescription: Bought this router in March ‘23 and this early March ‘24 started having dropouts in my WiFi connections where I have to power cycle this router every other day to keep WiFi connections to my devices. FW on the app says router is up to date so not sure what is causing this issue.

I've had this router for well over a year now and have noticed, largely, the following things.1: It cannot handle more than 2 devices running high speed/sized download speed.2: the coverage range is probably half of advertised, if not less.3: it's not worth the price

It was a great router until it quit connecting to my fiber internet. I don't know exactly what happened but my guess is that a surge in the power is what caused something to short even though I have it plugged into a GFCI power strip thing for that to not happen. But was good for like a month or something. I ended up going with a nighthawk because I need my internet for work. So had to get another router asap. Like the next day asap. If you are in rural area, id probably go with nighthawk. Amazon did make it right for me so that's a plus

reviewTitle: Hard to connectd to config site
reviewDescription: The URL to get to the configure site is usually not available without plugging my laptop into the using with a network cable.  Minor issue: The indicator light labels are too tiny for my old eyes to discern.

reviewTitle: MADE NO DIFFERENCE. WIFI STILL THE SAME
reviewDescription: Set it up but it did not increase my signal nor does it reach all places in my house. Maybe it's not set up correctly but it says it is.

That's the thought going through my head constantly. My only relief is that every other router on the market has issues so it's unavoidable. I initially thought the WiFi was fantastic but after 2-4hrs the WiFi looses it NOS I guess. It just goes into snail mode. I bought this router for its multiple ports hoping to clean up the paths to my computers and stay cool while doing it. WiFi thankfully wasn't something I was trying to upgrade anyway as I AP mode my DECOs mesh net to provide that.The router was a letdown but I suppose with everything shifting to a VPN market things will only get worse.
I bought this modem but the speed it’s too slow before a time, I have checked the cable and other devices but the negotiation speed never rise.
If you're using any Roku devices on your network, be aware Roku does not support wifi 6.  Not a TL Link problem but wifi 6 problem.

reviewTitle: Initial experience is a mixed bag
reviewDescription: So let's start out by saying this is an expensive router. At this price, I expect no issues whatsoever. However, here's the experience I've had within the first few days. The first thing I did was downloaded the most recent firmware (as of 9/20/20) which is Archer AX6000(US)_V1_200714. I set the Wifi to Smart Wifi, the 5Ghz signal either no longer showed up on my devices or it was not allowing me to log into it. Note that the 2Ghz and 5Ghz SSIDs both have the same password so it wasn't an issue of me hitting the wrong password between the two. Then the 5Ghz SSID simply wouldn't show up. I went back into the router and turned off Smart Wifi which then, in the UI, split the 2Ghz and 5Ghz channels and let me put in settings on each. When using "Auto" for channel selection, the 5Ghz SSID still didn't show up in devices. I then chose a manual channel (48) and rebooted. Now 5Ghz SSID did appear on devices. Great. But channel 48 was busy around me, 144 was clear, so I chose 144, saved and rebooted. 5Ghz showed up on 144 for an hour or so but then I noticed I was connecting to 5Ghz on 48 again. I went back into the router UI and now am seeing that in the dashboard the 5Ghz signal is on channel 48 but in the advanced setup on 5Ghz, it's still set to 144.I also notice that a lot of settings can be set and you hit save in the UI and you expect that setting to be working as expected but it actually doesn't get applied until you reboot the router.wtf???I don't have too much time to play with this but if this continues to be an issue for the next week or two, I will probably end up returning this thing.For the price, I really should not be seeing these issues at all.
This unit works great, it has at least double the coverage my old unit had. Very simple to install and very good installation as well.

reviewTitle: Routers are different per companies cable
reviewDescription: Who knew, the last router I had for about 8 years wouldn't work with this new company in our area? I was fed up with the rental on the rental fees & constant increases.  I bought my first TP-link router & was so happy with it, I asked the installation guy to pick what I needed to make his companies internet work & he recommended TP-Link also.  That made this customers day.

reviewTitle: Works great, easy to set uo
reviewDescription: I'm a new Spectrum customer and needed a router because who wants to pay them $8 a month to lease one for the rest of their life?I had this set up in no time. Great range across multiple rooms. No complaints at all.
My apartment isn’t that big but having multiple devices this modem makes everything non buffer
This router is amazing!  I never realized how fast 6G could be!  I've also got fiber optic internet, and a gaming computer attached.  Works flawlessly!  Thanks TP Link for such a great product!

Most of all, I love the price of this router!  I got it for only $62.00.  I have it hooked up in my living room, and the signal reaches all the way to my bedroom and keeps me connected to the internet very well.  I'm not very techy and hate to set things like this up, but the instructions they provided helped me to do it all by myself.  I was very pleased about that.
Much better coverage than previous router. Very pleased.

reviewTitle: Best Router I Have Ever Owned
reviewDescription: This router is awesome. I was having all kinds of streaming problems with my old router, but this one works so well!!! No spinning circles on anything I stream. Downloads are super fast. Cox tried to get me to buy the spyware Contour Router, but I got this instead and am very happy with my purchase.
So far so good. Bought for the sole purpose of replacing older unit
Carries lots of data at once

reviewTitle: Worked great at first but then became very unstable
reviewDescription: Upgraded from a 4-year old Asus router due to a gradual increase in devices over the years - I have about 50 devices (including a dozen Chromecasts streaming Hulu Live TV among other things) and although the Asus did fairly well, I noticed some trouble when there was a lot of traffic, especially streaming. Memory and CPU would max out 100% of the time and streaming would be interrupted. I upgraded to this router for the additional processing horsepower, enhanced range, and future WiFi 6 (AX) support. I also considered the Asus equivalent as I have been a long time Asus user but I went with this one for the additional antennas, better processing/co-processing and overall reputation if TP-Link products. i would love to have both in hand to test but that's a little more buy/return effort than I wanted to do. I believe Asus also makes great products.The router setup was extremely easy with the Tether app via bluetooth - the best I've seen in fact. I was up and running within minutes and had all my tweaking done in about an hour. Tweaking meaning setting up IPV6, custom DNS servers, etc. I have a single SSID for both 2.4 and 5.0 so that the clients can connect to whichever they find better. Right now it is about half and half. One note about the tether app - it will stay in bluetooth mode (meaning you have to be near the router) unless you enable remote management in the router settings. It is handy for managing the router without logging into the browser page, although I will say that not all options are available in the app and I found the browser setup to work very well.So far the performance and range of the router has been excellent with the exception of one thing. I was experiencing difficulty connecting some of my apple products to the 2.4GHz radio. After an email to TP-Link tech support (which was replied to very quickly), they asked me to turn off AX support in the 2.4GHz radio. I turned it off for 2.4 (and 5.0 simply because there are no AX clients yet for either anyway) and it immediately fixed the problem but I still have trouble connecting on occasion to the 2.4GHz radio. It begs the question why you would have to turn off a feature but I'm trusting there will be a firmware fix down the road before I have any AX clients and to fix the iPhone connectivity issue. If not I would be inclined to come back here and downgrade the rating since a large part of the cost of this router is AX compatibility.I have 115Mb/s internet service and I get that or very very close everywhere in my two story plus basement home. I'm sure it covers the yard too but I haven't tested it well since it is winter. Using a throughput app I get gigabit speeds near the router and 600-900 on other floors even in the far corners. So overall it should suit my needs as I am hoping 500Mb/s service or better will be available at some point for my area. All my smart devices (bulbs, plugs, thermostats, vacuum, cameras etc) work perfectly. This is one reason I went with a single router rather than a mesh system - I read reports of smart devices having difficulty with some of the mesh systems. I have not tried them however.Overall I'm pleased with a little more testing to do before my return period is up. I hope they keep up with firmware updates and add some more features such as the ability to have a timed guest network (I used that all the time on my Asus router for parties, it would remove the guest network at a set time so I didn't have to remember to go back in and turn it off) and the ability to set up multiple guest networks (not as important for me). It's an expensive router but hopefully it will last me several years, and that they will enable the WiFi-6/AX features.UPDATE: After a few weeks with the router, I'm having some more issues. iPhone products are disconnecting and the router is going offline and online about 2-3 times per day, which then disconnects many of my smart home products. Some of those products wouldn't reconnect (especially the cameras) without a full power cycle of the router. I've been working with tech support and I'm still hopeful to get a firmware fix to help. Otherwise, I'm going back to Asus as I have always found those to be extremely robust. Until I figure it all out, I'm downgrading this rating to 3 stars. If I have to return, I'll downgrade it again to 1.UPDATE 2/11/19: Unfortunately I'm returning. As I said above, the router has a lot of potential but it's simply not ready for release. I don't know if it is bad hardware or bad firmware but the thing goes offline several times a day. Despite working with tech support (who is very responsive and they do try to help), I can't get this thing to stay online and be stable. I ordered an Asus RT-AX88U and so far it is outstanding. Performance is excellent and it hasn't gone offline or rebooted in a week. I should've never left Asus!

reviewTitle: "UNCLE!" I quit. Ethernet won't connect - Unknown Network - fix/break, fix and break - I'm exhausted
reviewDescription: I didn't WANT a new router, but Norton terminated support for the Norton Core router and even without the software it won't work as a router anymore. I upgraded to this AX6000 - I wanted a router with more ethernet ports and an interface I could use from my PC (I don’t want just an ap or on my phone). I thought the newest option for mesh would be a good option to go with. It’s been nothing but a time-sucking royal pain that is completely unreliable. If I could throw it through the window at this point, I would. But then I wouldn’t be able to write this review, so I’m looking for something that has less bells and whistles and actually works.Issue 1 - ethernet: ethernet doesn't work on at least half my devices. Ethernet - the simplest of connections - just a plug, no drama. Wrong. Days trying to figure out why it won't assign the gateway address, doing all sorts of crap from every website I can find that has some kind of solution. Once I get it fixed, another has the same problem. Every day, and sometimes multiple times a day. I have spent so much time with so many different things, and then only to have to revisit the same problem on other ether connections. Some are win10, some win11, 1 for my solar system (no idea what OS); some directly connected, some thru a hub, some through a switch. All have the same issue at various times, and I cannot figure out ANY kind of commonality, cause, or fix. All worked fine with the old router. I’ve changed the lease time, theIssue 2 – interface: Nothing in the interface is “sortable” and I have to scroll through pages in two different places to see what is connected. There’s a network page that shows some info, but not all the info. So I have to go to the more detailed page, that shows different info. Not sure why all of it can’t be shown on one page (selectable and sortable). Pain to troubleshoot.Issue 3 – tech support: Mostly useless. I tried chat, and got the standard runaround with the first call. The second call had a good tech – listened to my problem, asked the right questions, and didn’t waste my time. He determined that the problem was my tp-link switch, and sent me an RMA. That wasn’t the problem – because eventually on one of the many permutations of changing settings on the PCs, pulling wires, resetting the router, and generally doing everything two or three times (or more, for the upteemth time) I hit the right combo of technical aerobatics and the PC connected. So, as I suspected, the switch was fine. As was the cable. As was the port. As was, as was … you get the idea. No definable or repeatable circumstances or solution.Right now I have just one PC connected by ethernet. And my solar reconnected (finally) but it no longer knows its name and identifies as “unknown” even though I have edited its name and it has shown up fine, by name, after most of the resets.On wireless - we thought the Range Extender might be confusing things. It’s verified to be compatible with this router. We changed it’s names, its location, it’s pw, connected and not connected - we did discover that everything wireless seemed to find just the router, so we’ve pulled that out completely to make troubleshooting easier.I’ll quit now, so I can go search for a new router. Too late to send this one back, but it’s not going to stay on my network. I don’t have time or energy to babysit the thing. As I sit here my internet connection has dropped in and out at least 5 times. Now that I’m thinking about it, wondering if this is also what’s causing the “spottiness” on our streamed content, too. You can bet its where I’m placing the blame.

reviewTitle: Chat tech support only & can't get it to work
reviewDescription: My best friend is in TelCom and I used to work for him so I know the difference between an RJ45 and RJ11 or a Cat 5 cable and flat Cat 7 patch cables, not to mention a couple of scratch build computers in the early age of computing. I am by no means an expert with all things computing, but I believe (probably my first mistake) that have a bit more knowledge than the typical consumer when it comes to computers and peripherals.I work from home and deal with a lot of research and large data files.  The stay at home order has crippled my  ability to get anything done because of the massive "streaming" being done eating up bandwidth by those stuck at home so I paid 3k to have fiber-optic brought to my house and get out from under the local cable internet suppliers.  I did my research and this model came in the top 3 of virtually every review I looked at, some saying it was not as fast as some or possibly had a couple less features but they all pretty much said it was a solid reliable choice that would be able to "upgrade" as technology advanced and you did not need to be up on the latest in the techworld to get it up and running. So I chose this model.  Fiber optic gets installed and I make sure to do all the very simple instructions to set up the router, making sure I do them "in order", and.... nothing. Bright red light means no internet connectivity. I tried trouble shooting for an hour to no avail.  So I call my fiber optic ISP and ask them why I have no service and they tell me everything checks out and that they see an AX6000 connected to the system with an IP and Mac address of xxx ..... So if they can see my router why is my router not working?  So I go to tech support which by the way is only currently open 4pm to 8am PST due to the pandemic and only available in chat form, but fortunately its 5:30pm and I have a laptop connected to my old internet which I have not cancelled yet. I am now chat queue #16 not bad should not take long. 6:30pm rolls in and "how may we help you". I explain the issue, and we work through a couple of things with no resolution. Then a shift change happens at the tech support group and I get a new tech who says unplug the Ethernet cable and plug it directly into your computer's Ethernet port, which I do and suddenly my desktop is screaming on the internet at 700Mbs down and up (tested). Now plug it back into router, reboot the router and voila bright red = no signal.So I know the internet connection is working and the issue is the router......  We try several more attempts to fix it and at 10pm (yes 3.5hrs later) the tech says that this needs to be sent to their senior tech level support and that they will be contacting me by email within 1 business day to get things fixed. I ask what hours the senior techs work and the answer is 6 am to 6pm pst, my time zone. That was Thursday night, its now Saturday. Last I checked Friday is a business day and the tech said they work 6-6 in my time zone so its not like there is a time difference issue.So I still don't have my really expensive WiFi router working and it is past my return date because it took so long for the fiber optic to get installed during the lockdown in my state and I am NOT happy.  Note that not only do I have a brand new fiber optic internet connection that we proved worked, I also upgraded my computer to a gen 10 Intel I-9 with a WiFi 6 enabled motherboard. Not trying to impress, in fact the exact opposite, all of my equipment is brand new and at the high end of the personal computer tech world. So connecting this router should have been plug and play in about 15 minutes.  More than 5 hours of attempting to get it working and I have nothing to show for it.  As of right now I cannot recommend that anyone buy this router.I will update if this gets resolved or if I use it as a paperweight.

reviewTitle: Unable to set admin name and password the first step in set up
reviewDescription: I received the router late in the day after it was “out for delivery” in the afternoon.  It is possible to set up the router without using their mobile app and connecting it to the internet. Power it up which generates a WiFi channel with a device (ipad, iPhone, Mac) and use it to change to an admin name and password to set up.  I couldn’t get past the initial step. I could log into the router which produced a screen asking for the serial number to be entered.  I entered it.  Many times.  Each time it resulted in a screen saying the entered information didn’t match what was saved on the router.  I went to the Tp-link support site and attempted a chat. It occurred, but the person there couldn’t understand the problem for a long time and told me that there was no portion of the start up program that requested the serial number of the router.  She wanted screen shots which I couldn’t produce while chatting.  I had to ask for the case no. And address to email the screenshots.Basically, I was told that my problem couldn’t occur and they couldn’t provide a solution without seeing it.I am not a tech guy, but I have set up many routers over the years and never had 1) a problem like this, and 2) never been told that I couldn’t be having the problem I presented to the support group.  The support person did confirm that the serial number was valid and seemed to feel that was enough.I did find a page that indicated that solving this problem involves proving the router was sold in the US by a valid seller.  Chat support obviously wasn’t aware of it, although she did ask where i bought it.I’m trying to replace an ailing router before it dies and I probably will return this and go to another manufacturer rather than wait for a solution.  I wasn’t impressed and doubt there will be a rapid response.

reviewTitle: TP-Link refuses to update Firmware to address multiple port protocols resulting in UPNP/DMZ issues
reviewDescription: This was my first and last TP-Link product.I'm going to put this straight: If you play games on a PC don't waste your money. If you have a PC connecting to this at all it's not going to behave correctly. I've had nothing but problems using both wireless and wired.Every device in my house has issues with connection causing them to have to turn their WIFI off and on every few hours.- Windows 10+ PC's work when connected with ethernet, however, windows power management settings interfere with the router which is the absolute strangest thing I've ever encountered.- Windows 8 and below seem to work ok without issues.- Apple devices like a Macbook Pro, or iphone will require flipping the WIFI on and off every hour or so to get a regular connection.- Android devices seem to work ok with not many issues.Using a Smart Connect and having DCMP running will not allow your UPNP or DMZ device list to populate any clients which will in the end causes random packet loss and dropped connections from every gaming platform you could use. It will work fine for an hour or two and suddenly drop. Or it could decide to be finnicky for half an hour and drop every connection you try. Either way, say goodbye to the Smart Connect setting form the get-go.The client-side power management settings for the NIC interferes with the ARP packets that the router uses to populate the client lists. So you CAN NOT set up dedicated UPNP devices to prevent ports being handled improperly while gaming. This is super annoying if you are using any kind of peer to peer connection games like Helldivers 2 for example.Discovered the hosting issues after a year of ownership, so warranty is already gone, and can't return. Goodbye $200. Never buying TP-Link again.

reviewTitle: Dead In Less Than A Year
reviewDescription: Archer AX6000 : What an annoying, garbage device.When first received the router: worked great. Did all the setup. Great.One month later - right after return window ended. Ports 1-4 spontaneously stopped working. (Permanently)Was a nightmare to diagnose. Lost 50% of lan ports.Few months later, disconnect issues, and random restarts. Nothing in logs.Now, it's a paper weight, and can assume due to really poor design..The router is plugged into a high-end surge protector. We had one storm, quick, but it took down power.Electricity cycled twice, no equipment damaged. - But power was down for a few hours. This was a week ago.Router worked fine.. Till today.Unable to connect wifi. Unable to make wired connection to modem - endless 'connecting...' in menu.The only way to know that it's doing that is to have the 'internet' port unplugged, connect via ethernet, THEN plug in the internet connection. Otherwise you cannot even access the router interface.Wifi, regardless what menu shows, is now completely broken. Shows it's broadcasting. Am able to even see it IS broadcasting to devices. It just can't connect. To anything. Connection always fails. (Even tried factory reset). Only ethernet, when internet in is not plugged in. (Therefore, not a router, but a useless device)Such trash. Too many problems for what was a $200 device.. in under a year. I've had previous routers last 5+ years. But gave it away to family when moving.I do not believe the storm was the cause of death. I think it was the fact it power cycled a couple times. And it was going to die anyhow. It's had too many problems.Avoid this (Archer AX6000)

reviewTitle: FALSE ADVERTISING....Product does not deliver what it claims. see review for details (RIP OFF)
reviewDescription: This product was purchased 6 months ago and claims that it can receive up to 2.5gbps. after speaking with TECHNICAL SUPPORT from TP-Link. This is FALSE. By the way, this came directly from a tech support supervisor. The WAN port is supposed to receive up to 2.5gbps, however it actually limits you to 1gbps (only up to 90% max can be received) so 900mbps. THEN READ CAREFULLY ON THE LISTING... because even if you get that speed, this WIFI router can only deliver 30-60% of that speed being received depending on how close your device sits. This router also claims to have link aggregation. you are combining 2 of the 1gbps LAN ports to make a HIGH speed port. Also False. Max speed i cold get was 783mbps  combined on LAN. I spend over 1.5hrs combined time on the phone with tech support and got no where. I contacted Amazon and they told me they wont do anything because its over 30 days past purchase. DO NOT GET RIPPED OFF LIKE I DID. Purchase something else from a different company TP-LINK are liars and false advertisers.

reviewTitle: It's Fast, but neither one I ordered operated on 2.4ghz, one barely, the second not at all...
reviewDescription: UPDATE: 9/2/2022; Given that I really like the TP app and the specs of this model tend to mirror that of the most expensive routers relative to 2.4ghz, I decided to give it another try, ordered it again from Amazon. I configured it yesterday with the app, just enough to have it operating as I had a meeting to attend shortly. But..for whatever reason, the 2.4ghz was not sending a signal. NONE! Although the app allows for deactivation of smart connect, my thought was, perhaps I need to do this online. So I stuck my old one back online and headed out. Upon return, later that evening, I spent hours attempting to correct the 2.4ghz frequency. Multiple reboots of both my modem and this router proved helpful. Nothing worked, and in fact, I realized that NONE of the frequencies were operating! Finally, at midnight, I gave up and stuck my old router back online. So much for TP.Initial review of first router which I sent back:I was excited to receive this new router, as my three year old, expensive, Nighthawk gaming router was dropping devices and, at times, losing WIFI entirely. The app is fine to program with if you don't want to do much with the settings, however, it took me several resets to finally get everything going with it. I should have known an issue was lurking within the beast. Once it had the settings I required (I had to use the IP address and program with my laptop), it seemed to function just fine and exhibited lightning fast download and upload numbers. But...The 2.4G is necessary for my security cams, so I cannot utilize the "smart" feature which doles out the frequencies. Unfortunately, this particular unit didn't care what I wanted to use. The thing comes with the smart setting turned on, so I turned it off and programmed my bands with names etc. After applying the changes and saving, all looked fine. At least it looked that way! Unfortunately, the smart feature must have been faulty, as it would turn itself back on and the 4G would vanish. Several times I reset the router, each time with high hopes. The fact is, the 4G would not operate at all. Not once did the 2.4 GHZ signal appear, and all of my cameras and certain other  pieces of video equipment were inoperable as well. After several hours of frustration, I packed it up and ordered another, different brand, of equipment.

reviewTitle: Horrible signal, Poor USB performance - avoid if you want a network drive
reviewDescription: The wifi signal is s*** which is most important. I have a small house. It is basically the size of an average 2 bedroom apartment inside (about 1,000 sq ft) and one level. The router is mounted on the wall of my office aligned with the trim of the door. The doorway is in view of the TV in the living room and maybe 10-15 feet away from SHIELD device on tv stand. The wifi signal is about a quarter of the speed of the ethernet even that close. When I connect wifi in the same room as the router on any pc it is about 1/4 to 1/3 of the speed of ethernet. Even with router inches away. No settings changes have improved this.That being said, Wifi has mostly been functional enough as my main PC is ethernet connected anyway. But I wanted to transfer the external hard drive for my PLEX server (media server I run from home that has all of my digital movies and music) and plug it into the USB port of the router and add that as a network drive to use on the laptop that controls the PLEX server. It takes about 30 minutes for it to add folders and files when the network drive is mapped to one of my windows PCs. And then it just stops adding files. So in my movies folder there are 1100 movies for example. It only adds 500-900 of them when I do a refresh of the USB device in the router settings. Arbitrarily adding or not adding stuff.In my TV shows folder I have about 20 different series of shows with multiple seasons. It adds absolutely none of these most of the time as it seems it gets tired scanning the drive and just stops at arbitrarily different times when scanning.It often simply does not even show up as a device in windows. I would say it is because it is USB 2.0 and too slow, but it seems the USB port also lacks the proper power to even run it or the router cannot handle so many files while scanning via USB.This router has been a complete disappointment again and again. I bought a new one with USB 3.0 and a better range and I hope it works better.If you have a larger home especially avoid this router. Maybe the more expensive models will work better but they all seem to have USB 2.0 - a network drive is a wonderful thing to have, so even if right now you don't have one you may want one later.

reviewTitle: Poor Quality, Poor Service, Poor Corporate Policy
reviewDescription: The TP-Link Archer AX6000 worked for 4 days before it started intermittently loosing connections on the 2.4G band.  By  day 6 the 2.4G band stopped funtioning at all.  I have three printers and a number of IOT devices that only work on the 3.4G band and none of the are accessable now.  The TP-Link support personnel are friendly and do their best to help but link most consumer electronics support groups, the have little training, especially on diagnosing actual broken products.  Their training, if any, appears based on the assumptions that all problems are user/configuration problems.  In addition, TP-Link is overly ridged with their policies and have no path to circumvent them when there are unusual circumstances.  I cannot recommend that anyone purchase a TP-Link product.  I purchased two TP-Link products within a couple of days of each other and experienced problems with both.P.S.  TP-Link refused to take a return for refund after only the unit went belly up after only 7 days of use.  They will only replace the unit and for that, you have to pay shipping which in my case was $24+ by FEDEX ground. which was the cheapest.  I hope to good that FEDEX loses it or destroys it as that is the only way I can get my money back and I certainly do not want another TP-Link product.It took 3 more days once TP-Link admitted the unit was defective just to get an RMA number.  The instructions state that it may take upto 5 says after they receive the defective unit to process the return and then they will "graciously" ship it free of charge back to you by the economical, "hence the slowest", method possible.  However, the will ship it by a faster method if you are willing to pay.I think there is something rotten in Denmark or rather Amazon that this unit is listed as an "Amazon's choice".  I also have questions about Amazon's rating system when this unit has a four star rating when there are 12 pages, yes that pages not individual, of 1 star reviews for a WiFi 6 router.  Someone has to be skewing the numbers as WiFi 6 has not been out that long.  Amazon will not help you with this router.  When they say this unit comes with Amazon support, they mean that when you call them, they will conference in TP-Link support and remain silent in the background.  I feel very sorry for anyone who buys a TP-Link product, especially this router.Reading the one star reviews confirms there is a definite problem with the 2.4G band and TP-Link has done nothing to fix it.  I a wandering if there are enough customer's with defective units to start a class action law suite to for TP-Link to either fix the problem or refund our money!!!!!!

For some reason TP-Link routers suddenly stopped allowing online gameplay on the switch. I purchased this router to replace my previous one, thinking it was just old. But nope… no ability to connect and a severe lack of support around the issue. If you use Nintendo’s online subscription regularly, steer very clear of this brand now.
